/au-federal/fwa/2009/s56.title: Terms of a modern award or enterprise agreement contravening section55 have no effect
/au-federal/fwa/2009/s56.content:
A term of a modern award or enterprise agreement has no effect to the extent that it contravenes section55.
Subdivision B—Interaction between modern awards and enterprise agreements

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s57.title: Interaction between modern awards and enterprise agreements
/au-federal/fwa/2009/s57.content:
(1)A modern award does not apply to an employee in relation to particular employment at a time when an enterprise agreement applies to the employee in relation to that employment.
(2)If a modern award does not apply to an employee in relation to particular employment because of subsection(1), the award does not apply to an employer, or an employee organisation, in relation to the employee.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s57/1.content: A modern award does not apply to an employee in relation to particular employment at a time when an enterprise agreement applies to the employee in relation to that employment.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s57/2.content: If a modern award does not apply to an employee in relation to particular employment because of subsection(1), the award does not apply to an employer, or an employee organisation, in relation to the employee.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s57A.title: Designated outworker terms of a modern award continue to apply
/au-federal/fwa/2009/s57A.content:
(1)This section applies if, at a particular time:
(a)an enterprise agreement applies to an employer; and
(b)a modern award covers the employer (whether the modern award covers the employer in the employer’s capacity as an employer or an outworker entity); and
(c)the modern award includes one or more designated outworker terms.
(2)Despite section57, the designated outworker terms of the modern award apply at that time to the following:
(a)the employer;
(b)each employee who is both:
(i)a person to whom the enterprise agreement applies; and
(ii)a person who is covered by the modern award;
(c)each employee organisation that is covered by the modern award.
(3)To avoid doubt:
(a)designated outworker terms of a modern award can apply to an employer under subsection(2) even if none of the employees of the employer is an outworker; and
(b)to the extent to which designated outworker terms of a modern award apply to an employer, an employee or an employee organisation because of subsection(2), the modern award applies to the employer, employee or organisation.
Subdivision C—Interaction between one or more enterprise agreements

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s57A/1.content: This section applies if, at a particular time:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s57A/1/a.content: an enterprise agreement applies to an employer; and

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s57A/1/b.content: a modern award covers the employer (whether the modern award covers the employer in the employer’s capacity as an employer or an outworker entity); and

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s57A/1/c.content: the modern award includes one or more designated outworker terms.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s57A/2.content: Despite section57, the designated outworker terms of the modern award apply at that time to the following:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s57A/2/i.content: a person to whom the enterprise agreement applies; and

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s57A/2/ii.content: a person who is covered by the modern award;

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s57A/2/c.content: each employee organisation that is covered by the modern award.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s57A/3/a.content: designated outworker terms of a modern award can apply to an employer under subsection(2) even if none of the employees of the employer is an outworker; and

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s57A/3/b.content: to the extent to which designated outworker terms of a modern award apply to an employer, an employee or an employee organisation because of subsection(2), the modern award applies to the employer, employee or organisation. Subdivision C—Interaction between one or more enterprise agreements

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s58.title: Only one enterprise agreement can apply to an employee
/au-federal/fwa/2009/s58.content:
Only one enterprise agreement can apply to an employee
(1)Only one enterprise agreement can apply to an employee at a particular time.
General rule—later agreement does not apply until earlier agreement passes its nominal expiry date
(2)If:
(a)an enterprise agreement (theearlier agreement) applies to an employee in relation to particular employment; and
(b)another enterprise agreement (thelater agreement) that covers the employee in relation to the same employment comes into operation; and
(c)subsections(3), (4) and (5) do not apply;
(d)if the earlier agreement has not passed its nominal expiry date:
(i)the later agreement cannot apply to the employee in relation to that employment until the earlier agreement passes its nominal expiry date; and
(ii)the earlier agreement ceases to apply to the employee in relation to that employment when the earlier agreement passes its nominal expiry date, and can never so apply again; or
(e)if the earlier agreement has passed its nominal expiry date—the earlier agreement ceases to apply to the employee when the later agreement comes into operation, and can never so apply again.
Special rule—supported bargaining agreement replaces single‑enterprise agreement
(3)If:
(a)a single‑enterprise agreement applies to an employee in relation to particular employment; and
(b)a supported bargaining agreement that covers the employee in relation to the same employment comes into operation;
the single‑enterprise agreement ceases to apply to the employee when the supported bargaining agreement comes into operation, and can never so apply again.
Special rule—single‑enterprise agreement replaces single interest employer agreement
(4)If:
(a)a single interest employer agreement applies to an employee in relation to particular employment; and
(b)a single‑enterprise agreement that covers the employee in relation to the same employment comes into operation;
the single interest employer agreement ceases to apply to the employee when the single‑enterprise agreement comes into operation, and can never so apply again.
Special rule—single‑enterprise agreement replaces supported bargaining agreement
(5)If:
(a)a supported bargaining agreement applies to an employee in relation to particular employment; and
(b)a single‑enterprise agreement that covers the employee in relation to the same employment comes into operation;
the supported bargaining agreement ceases to apply to the employee when the single‑enterprise agreement comes into operation, and can never so apply again.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s58/1.content: Only one enterprise agreement can apply to an employee at a particular time. Only one enterprise agreement can apply to an employee General rule—later agreement does not apply until earlier agreement passes its nominal expiry date

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s58/2/a.content: an enterprise agreement (theearlier agreement) applies to an employee in relation to particular employment; and

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s58/2/b.content: another enterprise agreement (thelater agreement) that covers the employee in relation to the same employment comes into operation; and

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s58/2/d.content: if the earlier agreement has not passed its nominal expiry date:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s58/2/i.content: the later agreement cannot apply to the employee in relation to that employment until the earlier agreement passes its nominal expiry date; and

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s58/2/ii.content: the earlier agreement ceases to apply to the employee in relation to that employment when the earlier agreement passes its nominal expiry date, and can never so apply again; or

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s58/2/e.content: if the earlier agreement has passed its nominal expiry date—the earlier agreement ceases to apply to the employee when the later agreement comes into operation, and can never so apply again. Special rule—supported bargaining agreement replaces single‑enterprise agreement

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s58/3/a.content: a single‑enterprise agreement applies to an employee in relation to particular employment; and

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s58/3/b.content: a supported bargaining agreement that covers the employee in relation to the same employment comes into operation; the single‑enterprise agreement ceases to apply to the employee when the supported bargaining agreement comes into operation, and can never so apply again. Special rule—single‑enterprise agreement replaces single interest employer agreement

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s58/4/a.content: a single interest employer agreement applies to an employee in relation to particular employment; and

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s58/4/b.content: a single‑enterprise agreement that covers the employee in relation to the same employment comes into operation; the single interest employer agreement ceases to apply to the employee when the single‑enterprise agreement comes into operation, and can never so apply again. Special rule—single‑enterprise agreement replaces supported bargaining agreement

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s58/5/a.content: a supported bargaining agreement applies to an employee in relation to particular employment; and

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s58/5/b.content: a single‑enterprise agreement that covers the employee in relation to the same employment comes into operation; the supported bargaining agreement ceases to apply to the employee when the single‑enterprise agreement comes into operation, and can never so apply again.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s59.title: Guide to this Part
/au-federal/fwa/2009/s59.content:
This Partcontains the National Employment Standards.
Division2 identifies the National Employment Standards, the detail of which is set out in Divisions3 to 12.
Division13 contains miscellaneous provisions relating to the National Employment Standards.
The National Employment Standards are minimum standards that apply to theemployment ofnational system employees. Part2‑1 (which deals with the core provisions for this Chapter) contains the obligation for employers to comply with the National Employment Standards (see section44).
The National Employment Standards also underpin what can be included in modern awards and enterprise agreements. Part2‑1 provides that the National Employment Standards cannot be excluded by modern awards or enterprise agreements, and contains other provisions about the interaction between the National Employment Standards and modern awards or enterprise agreements (see sections55 and 56).
Divisions2, 2A and 3 of Part6‑3 extend the operation of the parental leave, paid family and domestic violence leave and notice of termination provisions of the National Employment Standards to employees not otherwise covered by those provisions.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s60.title: Meanings ofemployeeandemployer
/au-federal/fwa/2009/s60.content: In this Part,employeemeans a national system employee, andemployermeans a national system employer.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s61.title: The National Employment Standards are minimum standards applying to employment of employees

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s61/1.content: This Part sets minimum standards that apply to the employment of employees which cannot be displaced, even if an enterprise agreement includes terms of the kind referred to in subsection55(5).

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s61/2.content: The minimum standards relate to the following matters:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s61/2/e.content: personal/carer’s leave, compassionate leave and paid family and domestic violence leave (Division7);

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s61/2/i.content: notice of termination and redundancy pay (Division11);

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s62.title: Maximum weekly hours

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s62/1.content: An employer must not request or require an employee to work more than the following number of hours in a week unless the additional hours are reasonable: Maximum weekly hours of work

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s62/1/a.content: for a full‑time employee—38 hours; or

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s62/1/b.content: for an employee who is not a full‑time employee—the lesser of:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s62/1/ii.content: the employee’s ordinary hours of work in a week. Employee may refuse to work unreasonable additional hours

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s62/2.content: The employee may refuse to work additional hours (beyond those referred to in paragraph(1)(a) or (b)) if they are unreasonable. Determining whether additional hours are reasonable

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s62/3.content: In determining whether additional hours are reasonable or unreasonable for the purposes of subsections(1) and (2), the following must be taken into account:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s62/3/a.content: any risk to employee health and safety from working the additional hours;

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s62/3/b.content: the employee’s personal circumstances, including family responsibilities;

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s62/3/c.content: the needs of the workplace or enterprise in which the employee is employed;

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s62/3/d.content: whether the employee is entitled to receive overtime payments, penalty rates or other compensation for, or a level of remuneration that reflects an expectation of, working additional hours;

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s62/3/e.content: any notice given by the employer of any request or requirement to work the additional hours;

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s62/3/f.content: any notice given by the employee of his or her intention to refuse to work the additional hours;

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s62/3/g.content: the usual patterns of work in the industry, or the part of an industry, in which the employee works;

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s62/3/h.content: the nature of the employee’s role, and the employee’s level of responsibility;

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s62/3/i.content: whether the additional hours are in accordance with averaging terms included under section63 in a modern award or enterprise agreement that applies to the employee, or with an averaging arrangement agreed to by the employer and employee under section64;

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s62/3/j.content: any other relevant matter. Authorised leave or absence treated as hours worked

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s62/4.content: For the purposes of subsection(1), the hours an employee works in a week are taken to include any hours of leave, or absence, whether paid or unpaid, that the employee takes in the week and that are authorised:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s62/4/b.content: by or under a term or condition of the employee’s employment; or

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s62/4/c.content: by or under a law of the Commonwealth, a State or a Territory, or an instrument in force under such a law.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s63.title: Modern awards and enterprise agreements may provide for averaging of hours of work
/au-federal/fwa/2009/s63.content:
(1)A modern award or enterprise agreement may include terms providing for the averaging of hours of work over a specified period. The average weekly hours over the period must not exceed:
(a)for a full‑time employee—38 hours; or
(b)for an employee who is not a full‑time employee—the lesser of:
(i)38 hours; and
(ii)the employee’s ordinary hours of work in a week.
(2)The terms of a modern award or enterprise agreement may provide for average weekly hours that exceed the hours referred to in paragraph(1)(a) or (b) if the excess hours are reasonable for the purposes of subsection62(1).

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s63/1.content: A modern award or enterprise agreement may include terms providing for the averaging of hours of work over a specified period. The average weekly hours over the period must not exceed:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s63/1/a.content: for a full‑time employee—38 hours; or

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s63/1/b.content: for an employee who is not a full‑time employee—the lesser of:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s63/1/ii.content: the employee’s ordinary hours of work in a week.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s63/2.content: The terms of a modern award or enterprise agreement may provide for average weekly hours that exceed the hours referred to in paragraph(1)(a) or (b) if the excess hours are reasonable for the purposes of subsection62(1).

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s64.title: Averaging of hours of work for award/agreement free employees
/au-federal/fwa/2009/s64.content:
(1)An employer and an award/agreement free employee may agree in writing to an averaging arrangement under which hours of work over a specified period of not more than 26 weeks are averaged. The average weekly hours over the specified period must not exceed:
(a)for a full‑time employee—38 hours; or
(b)for an employee who is not a full‑time employee—the lesser of:
(i)38 hours; and
(ii)the employee’s ordinary hours of work in a week.
(2)The agreed averaging arrangement may provide for average weekly hours that exceed the hours referred to in paragraph(1)(a) or (b) if the excess hours are reasonable for the purposes of subsection62(1).

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s64/1.content: An employer and an award/agreement free employee may agree in writing to an averaging arrangement under which hours of work over a specified period of not more than 26 weeks are averaged. The average weekly hours over the specified period must not exceed:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s64/1/a.content: for a full‑time employee—38 hours; or

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s64/1/b.content: for an employee who is not a full‑time employee—the lesser of:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s64/1/ii.content: the employee’s ordinary hours of work in a week.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s64/2.content: The agreed averaging arrangement may provide for average weekly hours that exceed the hours referred to in paragraph(1)(a) or (b) if the excess hours are reasonable for the purposes of subsection62(1).

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s65.title: Requests for flexible working arrangements
/au-federal/fwa/2009/s65.content:
Employee may request change in working arrangements
(1)If:
(a)any of the circumstances referred to in subsection(1A) apply to an employee; and
(b)the employee would like to change his or her working arrangements because of those circumstances;
then the employee may request the employer for a change in working arrangements relating to those circumstances.
(1A)The following are the circumstances:
(aa)the employee is pregnant;
(a)the employee is the parent, or has responsibility for the care, of a child who is of school age or younger;
(b)the employee is a carer (within the meaning of theCarer Recognition Act 2010);
(c)the employee has a disability;
(d)the employee is 55 or older;
(e)the employee is experiencing family and domestic violence;
(f)the employee provides care or support to a member of the employee’s immediate family, or a member of the employee’s household, who requires care or support because the member is experiencing family and domestic violence.
(1B)To avoid doubt, and without limiting subsection(1), an employee who:
(a)is a parent, or has responsibility for the care, of a child; and
(b)is returning to work after taking leave in relation to the birth or adoption of the child;
may request to work part‑time to assist the employee to care for the child.
(2)The employee is not entitled to make the request unless:
(a)for an employee other than a casual employee—the employee has completed at least 12 months of continuous service with the employer immediately before making the request; or
(b)for a casual employee—the employee:
(i)is, immediately before making the request, a regular casual employee of the employer who has been employed on that basis for a sequence of periods of employment during a period of at least 12 months; and
(ii)has a reasonable expectation of continuing employment by the employer on a regular and systematic basis.
(2A)For the purposes of applying paragraph(2)(a) in relation to an employee who has had their employment changed under Division4A of Part2‑2, any period for which the employee was a regular casual employee of the employer is taken to be continuous service for the purposes of that paragraph.
Formal requirements
(3)The request must:
(a)be in writing; and
(b)set out details of the change sought and of the reasons for the change.
Agreeing to the request

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s65/1.content: If: Employee may request change in working arrangements

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s65/1/a.content: is a parent, or has responsibility for the care, of a child; and

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s65/1/b.content: is returning to work after taking leave in relation to the birth or adoption of the child; may request to work part‑time to assist the employee to care for the child.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s65/1/e.content: the employee is experiencing family and domestic violence;

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s65/1/f.content: the employee provides care or support to a member of the employee’s immediate family, or a member of the employee’s household, who requires care or support because the member is experiencing family and domestic violence. (1B)To avoid doubt, and without limiting subsection(1), an employee who:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s65/2.content: The employee is not entitled to make the request unless:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s65/2/a.content: for an employee other than a casual employee—the employee has completed at least 12 months of continuous service with the employer immediately before making the request; or

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s65/2/i.content: is, immediately before making the request, a regular casual employee of the employer who has been employed on that basis for a sequence of periods of employment during a period of at least 12 months; and

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s65/2/ii.content: has a reasonable expectation of continuing employment by the employer on a regular and systematic basis. (2A)For the purposes of applying paragraph(2)(a) in relation to an employee who has had their employment changed under Division4A of Part2‑2, any period for which the employee was a regular casual employee of the employer is taken to be continuous service for the purposes of that paragraph. Formal requirements

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s65/3/b.content: set out details of the change sought and of the reasons for the change. Agreeing to the request

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s65A.title: Responding to requests for flexible working arrangements
/au-federal/fwa/2009/s65A.content:
Responding to the request
(1)If, under subsection65(1), an employee requests an employer for a change in working arrangements relating to circumstances that apply to the employee, the employer must give the employee a written response to the request within 21 days.
(2)The response must:
(a)state that the employer grants the request; or
(b)if, following discussion between the employer and the employee, the employer and the employee agree to a change to the employee’s working arrangements that differs from that set out in the request—set out the agreed change; or
(c)subject to subsection(3)—state that the employer refuses the request and include the matters required by subsection(6).
(3)The employer may refuse the request only if:
(a)the employer has:
(i)discussed the request with the employee; and
(ii)genuinely tried to reach an agreement with the employee about making changes to the employee’s working arrangements to accommodate the circumstances mentioned in subsection(1); and
(b)the employer and the employee have not reached such an agreement; and
(c)the employer has had regard to the consequences of the refusal for the employee; and
(d)the refusal is on reasonable business grounds.
(4)To avoid doubt, subparagraph(3)(a)(ii) does not require the employer to agree to a change to the employee’s working arrangements if the employer would have reasonable business grounds for refusing a request for the change.
Reasonable business grounds for refusing requests
(5)Without limiting what are reasonable business grounds for the purposes of paragraph(3)(d) and subsection(4), reasonable business grounds for refusing a request include the following:
(a)that the new working arrangements requested would be too costly for the employer;
(b)that there is no capacity to change the working arrangements of other employees to accommodate the new working arrangements requested;
(c)that it would be impractical to change the working arrangements of other employees, or recruit new employees, to accommodate the new working arrangements requested;
(d)that the new working arrangements requested would be likely to result in a significant loss in efficiency or productivity;
(e)that the new working arrangements requested would be likely to have a significant negative impact on customer service.
Employer must explain grounds for refusal
(6)If the employer refuses the request, the written response under subsection(1) must:
(a)include details of the reasons for the refusal; and
(b)without limiting paragraph(a) of this subsection:
(i)set out the employer’s particular business grounds for refusing the request; and
(ii)explain how those grounds apply to the request; and
(c)either:
(i)set out the changes (other than the requested change) in the employee’s working arrangements that would accommodate, to any extent, the circumstances mentioned in subsection(1) and that the employer would be willing to make; or
(ii)state that there are no such changes; and
(d)set out the effect of sections65B and 65C.
Genuinely trying to reach an agreement
(7)This section does not affect, and is not affected by, the meaning of the expression “genuinely trying to reach an agreement”, or any variant of the expression, as used elsewhere in this Act.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s65A/1.content: If, under subsection65(1), an employee requests an employer for a change in working arrangements relating to circumstances that apply to the employee, the employer must give the employee a written response to the request within 21 days. Responding to the request

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s65A/2/a.content: state that the employer grants the request; or

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s65A/2/b.content: if, following discussion between the employer and the employee, the employer and the employee agree to a change to the employee’s working arrangements that differs from that set out in the request—set out the agreed change; or

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s65A/2/c.content: subject to subsection(3)—state that the employer refuses the request and include the matters required by subsection(6).

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s65A/3.content: The employer may refuse the request only if:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s65A/3/i.content: discussed the request with the employee; and

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s65A/3/ii.content: genuinely tried to reach an agreement with the employee about making changes to the employee’s working arrangements to accommodate the circumstances mentioned in subsection(1); and

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s65A/3/b.content: the employer and the employee have not reached such an agreement; and

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s65A/3/c.content: the employer has had regard to the consequences of the refusal for the employee; and

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s65A/3/d.content: the refusal is on reasonable business grounds.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s65A/4.content: To avoid doubt, subparagraph(3)(a)(ii) does not require the employer to agree to a change to the employee’s working arrangements if the employer would have reasonable business grounds for refusing a request for the change. Reasonable business grounds for refusing requests

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s65A/5.content: Without limiting what are reasonable business grounds for the purposes of paragraph(3)(d) and subsection(4), reasonable business grounds for refusing a request include the following:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s65A/5/a.content: that the new working arrangements requested would be too costly for the employer;

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s65A/5/b.content: that there is no capacity to change the working arrangements of other employees to accommodate the new working arrangements requested;

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s65A/5/c.content: that it would be impractical to change the working arrangements of other employees, or recruit new employees, to accommodate the new working arrangements requested;

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s65A/5/d.content: that the new working arrangements requested would be likely to result in a significant loss in efficiency or productivity;

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s65A/5/e.content: that the new working arrangements requested would be likely to have a significant negative impact on customer service. Employer must explain grounds for refusal

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s65A/6.content: If the employer refuses the request, the written response under subsection(1) must:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s65A/6/a.content: include details of the reasons for the refusal; and

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s65A/6/b.content: without limiting paragraph(a) of this subsection:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s65A/6/i.content: set out the changes (other than the requested change) in the employee’s working arrangements that would accommodate, to any extent, the circumstances mentioned in subsection(1) and that the employer would be willing to make; or

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s65A/6/ii.content: state that there are no such changes; and

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s65A/6/d.content: set out the effect of sections65B and 65C. Genuinely trying to reach an agreement

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s65A/7.content: This section does not affect, and is not affected by, the meaning of the expression “genuinely trying to reach an agreement”, or any variant of the expression, as used elsewhere in this Act.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s65B.title: Disputes about the operation of this Division
/au-federal/fwa/2009/s65B.content:
Application of this section
(1)This section applies to a dispute between an employer and an employee about the operation of this Division if:
(a)the dispute relates to a request by the employee to the employer under subsection65(1) for a change in working arrangements relating to circumstances that apply to the employee; and
(b)either:
(i)the employer has refused the request; or
(ii)21 days have passed since the employee made the request, and the employer has not given the employee a written response to the request under section65A.
Resolving disputes
(2)In the first instance, the parties to the dispute must attempt to resolve the dispute at the workplace level, by discussions between the parties.
FWC may deal with disputes
(3)If discussions at the workplace level do not resolve the dispute, a party to the dispute may refer the dispute to the FWC.
(4)If a dispute is referred under subsection(3):
(a)the FWC must first deal with the dispute by means other than arbitration, unless there are exceptional circumstances; and
(b)the FWC may deal with the dispute by arbitration in accordance with section65C.
Representatives
(5)The employer or employee may appoint a person or industrial association to provide the employer or employee (as the case may be) with support or representation for the purposes of:
(a)resolving the dispute; or
(b)the FWC dealing with the dispute.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s65B/1.content: This section applies to a dispute between an employer and an employee about the operation of this Division if: Application of this section

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s65B/1/a.content: the dispute relates to a request by the employee to the employer under subsection65(1) for a change in working arrangements relating to circumstances that apply to the employee; and

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s65B/1/i.content: the employer has refused the request; or

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s65B/1/ii.content: 21 days have passed since the employee made the request, and the employer has not given the employee a written response to the request under section65A. Resolving disputes

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s65B/2.content: In the first instance, the parties to the dispute must attempt to resolve the dispute at the workplace level, by discussions between the parties. FWC may deal with disputes

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s65B/3.content: If discussions at the workplace level do not resolve the dispute, a party to the dispute may refer the dispute to the FWC.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s65B/4.content: If a dispute is referred under subsection(3):

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s65B/4/a.content: the FWC must first deal with the dispute by means other than arbitration, unless there are exceptional circumstances; and

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s65B/4/b.content: the FWC may deal with the dispute by arbitration in accordance with section65C. Representatives

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s65B/5.content: The employer or employee may appoint a person or industrial association to provide the employer or employee (as the case may be) with support or representation for the purposes of:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s65B/5/b.content: the FWC dealing with the dispute.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s65C.title: Arbitration
/au-federal/fwa/2009/s65C.content:
(1)For the purposes of paragraph65B(4)(b), the FWC may deal with the dispute by arbitration by making any of the following orders:
(a)if the employer has not given the employee a written response to the request under section65A—an order that the employer be taken to have refused the request;
(b)if the employer refused the request:
(i)an order that it would be appropriate for the grounds on which the employer refused the request to be taken to have been reasonable business grounds; or
(ii)an order that it would be appropriate for the grounds on which the employer refused the request to be taken not to have been reasonable business grounds;
(e)if the FWC is satisfied that the employer has not responded, or has not responded adequately, to the employee’s request under section65A—an order that the employer take such further steps as the FWC considers appropriate, having regard to the matters in section65A;
(f)subject to subsection(3) of this section:
(i)an order that the employer grant the request; or
(ii)an order that the employer make specified changes (other than the requested changes) in the employee’s working arrangements to accommodate, to any extent, the circumstances mentioned in paragraph65B(1)(a).
(2)In making an order under subsection(1), the FWC must take into account fairness between the employer and the employee.
(2A)The FWC must not make an order under paragraph(1)(e) or (f) that would be inconsistent with:
(a)a provision of this Act; or
(b)a term of a fair work instrument (other than an order made under that paragraph) that, immediately before the order is made, applies to the employer and employee.
(3)The FWC may make an order under paragraph(1)(f) only if the FWC is satisfied that there is no reasonable prospect of the dispute being resolved without the making of such an order.
(4)If the FWC makes an order under paragraph(1)(a), the employer is taken to have refused the request.
(5)If the FWC makes an order under paragraph(1)(b), the grounds on which the employer refuses the request are taken:
(a)for an order made under subparagraph(1)(b)(i)—to be reasonable business grounds; or
(b)for an order made under subparagraph(1)(b)(ii)—not to be reasonable business grounds.
Contravening an order under subsection(1)
(6)A person must not contravene a term of an order made under subsection(1).

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s65C/1.content: For the purposes of paragraph65B(4)(b), the FWC may deal with the dispute by arbitration by making any of the following orders:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s65C/1/a.content: if the employer has not given the employee a written response to the request under section65A—an order that the employer be taken to have refused the request;

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s65C/1/b.content: if the employer refused the request:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s65C/1/i.content: an order that the employer grant the request; or

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s65C/1/ii.content: an order that the employer make specified changes (other than the requested changes) in the employee’s working arrangements to accommodate, to any extent, the circumstances mentioned in paragraph65B(1)(a).

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s65C/1/e.content: if the FWC is satisfied that the employer has not responded, or has not responded adequately, to the employee’s request under section65A—an order that the employer take such further steps as the FWC considers appropriate, having regard to the matters in section65A;

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s65C/1/f.content: subject to subsection(3) of this section:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s65C/2.content: In making an order under subsection(1), the FWC must take into account fairness between the employer and the employee. (2A)The FWC must not make an order under paragraph(1)(e) or (f) that would be inconsistent with:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s65C/2/a.content: a provision of this Act; or

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s65C/2/b.content: a term of a fair work instrument (other than an order made under that paragraph) that, immediately before the order is made, applies to the employer and employee.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s65C/3.content: The FWC may make an order under paragraph(1)(f) only if the FWC is satisfied that there is no reasonable prospect of the dispute being resolved without the making of such an order.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s65C/4.content: If the FWC makes an order under paragraph(1)(a), the employer is taken to have refused the request.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s65C/5.content: If the FWC makes an order under paragraph(1)(b), the grounds on which the employer refuses the request are taken:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s65C/5/a.content: for an order made under subparagraph(1)(b)(i)—to be reasonable business grounds; or

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s65C/5/b.content: for an order made under subparagraph(1)(b)(ii)—not to be reasonable business grounds. Contravening an order under subsection(1)

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s65C/6.content: A person must not contravene a term of an order made under subsection(1).

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s66.title: State and Territory laws that are not excluded
/au-federal/fwa/2009/s66.content:
This Act is not intended to apply to the exclusion of laws of a State or Territory that provide employee entitlements in relation to flexible working arrangements, to the extent that those entitlements are more beneficial to employees than the entitlements under this Division.
CollapseDivision 4A—Casual employment
Subdivision A—Application of Division

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s66A.title: Division applies to casual employees etc.
/au-federal/fwa/2009/s66A.content:
(1)This Division applies in relation to an employee who is a casual employee.
(2)A reference in this Division to full‑time employment or part‑time employment is taken not to include employment for a specified period of time, for a specified task or for the duration of a specified season.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s66A/1.content: This Division applies in relation to an employee who is a casual employee.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s66A/2.content: A reference in this Division to full‑time employment or part‑time employment is taken not to include employment for a specified period of time, for a specified task or for the duration of a specified season.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s66AAA.title: Object of this Division
/au-federal/fwa/2009/s66AAA.content:
The object of this Division is to establish a framework for dealing with changes to casual employment status that:
(a)is quick, flexible and informal; and
(b)addresses the needs of employers and employees; and
(c)provides for the resolution of disputes to support employee choice about employment status.
Subdivision B—Employee choice about casual employment

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s66AAA/a.content: is quick, flexible and informal; and The object of this Division is to establish a framework for dealing with changes to casual employment status that:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s66AAA/b.content: addresses the needs of employers and employees; and

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s66AAA/c.content: provides for the resolution of disputes to support employee choice about employment status. Subdivision B—Employee choice about casual employment

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s66AAB.title: Employee notification
/au-federal/fwa/2009/s66AAB.content:
A casual employee may give an employer a written notification under this section if:
(a)having regard to subsections15A(1) to (4) and the employee’s current employment relationship with the employer, the employeebelieves that the employee no longer meets the requirements of those subsections; and
(b)the employee does not have a dispute with the employer relating to the operation of Division4A of Part2‑2 being dealt with under section66M (including by way of arbitration under section66MA) or under section739; and
(c)if the employer:
(i)is a small business employer at the time the notification is given—the employee has been employed by the employer for a period of at least 12 months beginning the day the employment started; or
(ii)is not a small business employer at the time the notification is given—the employee has been employed by the employer for a period of at least 6 months beginning the day the employment started; and
(d)in the period of 6 months before the day the notification is given, the employee has not:
(i)received a response from the employer under section66AAC not accepting a previous notification made under this section; or
(v)had a dispute with the employer relating to the operation of Division4A of Part2‑2 resolved under section66M (including by way of arbitration under section66MA) or under section739.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s66AAB/a.content: having regard to subsections15A(1) to (4) and the employee’s current employment relationship with the employer, the employeebelieves that the employee no longer meets the requirements of those subsections; and A casual employee may give an employer a written notification under this section if:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s66AAB/b.content: the employee does not have a dispute with the employer relating to the operation of Division4A of Part2‑2 being dealt with under section66M (including by way of arbitration under section66MA) or under section739; and

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s66AAB/i.content: received a response from the employer under section66AAC not accepting a previous notification made under this section; or

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s66AAB/ii.content: is not a small business employer at the time the notification is given—the employee has been employed by the employer for a period of at least 6 months beginning the day the employment started; and

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s66AAB/d.content: in the period of 6 months before the day the notification is given, the employee has not:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s66AAB/v.content: had a dispute with the employer relating to the operation of Division4A of Part2‑2 resolved under section66M (including by way of arbitration under section66MA) or under section739.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s66AAC.title: Employer response

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s66AAC/1.content: An employer must give an employee a written response to a notification given under section66AAB within 21 days after the notification is given to the employer. Timing of response Information that must be included in response

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s66AAC/2.content: The response must be in writing and include the following:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s66AAC/2/i.content: whether the employee is changing to full‑time employment or part‑time employment;

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s66AAC/2/ii.content: the employee’s hours of work after the change takes effect;

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s66AAC/2/b.content: if the employer accepts the notification—the following information:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s66AAC/2/iii.content: the day the employee’s change to full‑time employment or part‑time employment takes effect;

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s66AAC/2/c.content: if the employer does not accept the notification—reasons for the employer’s decision. Consulting with employee

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s66AAC/3.content: Before giving a response under subsection(1), the employer must consult with the employee about the notification and must, if the employer is accepting the notification, discuss the matters the employer intends to specify for the purposes of subparagraphs(2)(b)(i) to (iii). Grounds for employer to not accept notification

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s66AAC/4.content: For the purposes of subparagraph(2)(a)(ii), the employer may not accept the notification on any of the following grounds:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s66AAC/4/a.content: having regard to subsections15A(1) to (4) and the employee’s current employment relationship with the employer, the employee still meets the requirements of those subsections;

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s66AAC/4/b.content: there are fair and reasonable operational grounds for not accepting the notification;

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s66AAC/4/c.content: accepting the notification would result in the employer not complying with a recruitment or selection process required by or under a law of the Commonwealth or a State or a Territory.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s66AAC/5.content: For the purposes of paragraph(4)(b), fair and reasonable operational grounds for not accepting the notification include the following:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s66AAC/5/a.content: substantial changes would be required to the way in which work in the employer’s enterprise is organised;

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s66AAC/5/b.content: there would be significant impacts on the operation of the employer’s enterprise;

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s66AAC/5/c.content: substantial changes to the employee’s terms and conditions would be reasonably necessary to ensure the employer does not contravene a term of a fair work instrument that would apply to the employee as a full‑time employee or part‑time employee (as the case may be).

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s66AAD.title: Effect of employer acceptance of employee notification
/au-federal/fwa/2009/s66AAD.content:
(1)If an employer responds under section66AAC that the employer accepts an employee’s notification given under section66AAB, the employee is taken to be a full‑time employee or part‑time employee (as the case may be) beginning on the day specified in the response.
(2)The day specified in the response for the purposes of subsection(1) must be the first day of the employee’s first full pay period that starts after the day the employer response is given, unless the employer and employee agree to another day.
Subdivision D—Other provisions

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s66AAD/1.content: If an employer responds under section66AAC that the employer accepts an employee’s notification given under section66AAB, the employee is taken to be a full‑time employee or part‑time employee (as the case may be) beginning on the day specified in the response.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s66AAD/2.content: The day specified in the response for the purposes of subsection(1) must be the first day of the employee’s first full pay period that starts after the day the employer response is given, unless the employer and employee agree to another day. Subdivision D—Other provisions

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s66K.title: Effect of change

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s66K/a.content: this Act and any other law of the Commonwealth; To avoid doubt, an employee is taken, on and after the day specified in a notice for the purposes of subparagraph66AAC(2)(b)(iii), to be a full‑time employee or part‑time employee of the employer for the purposes of the following:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s66K/b.content: a law of a State or Territory;

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s66K/c.content: any fair work instrument that applies to the employee;

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s66L.title: Other rights and obligations

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s66L/1.content: An employer must not do any of the following in order to avoid any right or obligation under this Division:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s66L/1/a.content: reduce or vary an employee’s hours of work;

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s66L/1/b.content: change the employee’s pattern of work;

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s66L/2/a.content: requires an employee to change to full‑time employment or part‑time employment under this Division; or

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s66L/2/b.content: permits an employer to require an employee to change to full‑time employment or part‑time employment under this Division; or

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s66L/2/c.content: requires an employer to increase the hours of work of an employee who gives a notification to change to full‑time employment or part‑time employment under this Division.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s66L/3.content: To avoid doubt, each of the following is a workplace right within the meaning of Part3‑1:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s66L/3/a.content: giving an employer a notification under section66AAB;

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s66L/3/b.content: receiving a response from an employer in accordance with section66AAC;

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s66L/3/c.content: being taken to be a full‑time employee or part‑time employee under section66AAD;

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s66L/3/d.content: receiving an offer or notice in accordance with sections66B and 66C;

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s66L/3/e.content: accepting an offer and receiving a notice under section66E;

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s66L/3/f.content: participating in a dispute about the operation of this Division in accordance with sections66M and 66MA.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s66M.title: Disputes about the operation of this Division
/au-federal/fwa/2009/s66M.content:
Application of this section to disputes about employee choice
(1)This section applies to a dispute between an employer and an employee about the operation of Subdivision B of this Division.
Resolving disputes
(4)In the first instance, the parties to the dispute must attempt to resolve the dispute at the workplace level, by discussions between the parties.
FWC may deal with disputes
(5)If discussions at the workplace level do not resolve the dispute, a party to the dispute may refer the dispute to the FWC.
(6)If a dispute is referred under subsection(5):
(a)the FWC must first deal with the dispute by means other than arbitration, unless there are exceptional circumstances; and
(b)the FWC may deal with the dispute by arbitration in accordance with section66MA.
Representatives
(10)The employer or employee may appoint a person, or an employer organisation or employee organisation, that is entitled to represent the industrial interests of the employer or employee to provide the employer or employee (as the case may be) with support or representation for the purposes of:
(a)resolving the dispute; or
(b)the FWC dealing with the dispute.
Procedural rules
(11)Without limiting section609, the procedural rules may provide, in relation to a dispute between an employer and employee that has been referred to the FWC under subsection(5) of this section, for the joinder of the following as parties to the dispute:
(a)any other employee that has a dispute to which this section applies with the same employer;
(b)any employee organisation that is entitled to represent the industrial interests of such an employee.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s66M/1.content: This section applies to a dispute between an employer and an employee about the operation of Subdivision B of this Division. Application of this section to disputes about employee choice Resolving disputes

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s66M/4.content: In the first instance, the parties to the dispute must attempt to resolve the dispute at the workplace level, by discussions between the parties. FWC may deal with disputes

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s66M/5.content: If discussions at the workplace level do not resolve the dispute, a party to the dispute may refer the dispute to the FWC.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s66M/6.content: If a dispute is referred under subsection(5):

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s66M/6/a.content: the FWC must first deal with the dispute by means other than arbitration, unless there are exceptional circumstances; and

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s66M/6/b.content: the FWC may deal with the dispute by arbitration in accordance with section66MA. Representatives

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s66M/10.content: The employer or employee may appoint a person, or an employer organisation or employee organisation, that is entitled to represent the industrial interests of the employer or employee to provide the employer or employee (as the case may be) with support or representation for the purposes of:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s66M/10/b.content: the FWC dealing with the dispute. Procedural rules

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s66M/11.content: Without limiting section609, the procedural rules may provide, in relation to a dispute between an employer and employee that has been referred to the FWC under subsection(5) of this section, for the joinder of the following as parties to the dispute:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s66M/11/a.content: any other employee that has a dispute to which this section applies with the same employer;

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s66M/11/b.content: any employee organisation that is entitled to represent the industrial interests of such an employee.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s66MA/1.content: For the purposes of paragraph66M(6)(b), the FWC may deal with the dispute by arbitration, including by making any orders it considers appropriate, including (but not limited to) any order referred to in subsection(4) of this section. FWC may make any orders it considers appropriate

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s66MA/2.content: However, the FWC must not make an order under this section unless the FWC considers that it would be fair and reasonable to make the order.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s66MA/3.content: The FWC must not make an order under subsection(1) that would be inconsistent with:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s66MA/3/a.content: a provision of this Act; or

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s66MA/3/b.content: a term of a fair work instrument (other than an order made under that subsection) that, immediately before the order is made, applies to the employer and employee. Orders relating to employee choice

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s66MA/4.content: For the purposes of paragraph(1)(a), the orders are the following:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s66MA/4/a.content: that the employee continue to be treated as a casual employee;

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s66MA/4/b.content: that the employee be treated as a full‑time employee or part‑time employee (as the case may be) from the first day of the employee’s first full pay period that starts after the day the order is made, or such later day that the FWC considers appropriate.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s66MA/5.content: In considering whether to make, and the terms of, an order under subsection(1) (including an order referred to in subsection(4)) in relation to a dispute about the operation of Subdivision B of this Division (which deals with employee choice about casual employment), the FWC must:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s66MA/5/a.content: have regard to whether substantial changes to the employee’s terms and conditions would be reasonably necessary to ensure the employer does not contravene a term of a fair work instrument that would apply to the employee as a full‑time employee or part‑time employee; and

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s66MA/5/b.content: disregard conduct of the employer and employee that occurred after the employee gave the notification under section66AAB (which deals with employee choice notifications) to the employer. Contravening an order under subsection(1)

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s66MA/8.content: A person must not contravene a term of an order made under subsection(1).

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s67.title: General rule—employee must have completed at least 12 months of service
/au-federal/fwa/2009/s67.content:
Employees other than casual employees
(1)An employee, other than a casual employee, is not entitled to leave under this Division (other than unpaid pre‑adoption leave or unpaid no safe job leave)unless the employee has, or will have, completed at least 12 months of continuous service with the employer immediately before the date that applies under subsection(3).
(1A)For the purposes of applying subsection(1) in relation to an employee who has had their employment changed under Division4A of Part2‑2, any period for which the employee was a regular casual employee of the employer is taken to be continuous service for the purposes of that subsection.
Casual employees
(2)A casual employee, is not entitled to leave (other than unpaid pre‑adoption leave or unpaid no safe job leave) under this Division unless:
(a)the employee is, or will be, immediately before the date that applies under subsection(3), a regular casual employee of the employer who has been employed on that basis for a sequence of periods of employment during a period of at least 12 months; and
(b)but for:
(i)the birth or expected birth of the child; or
(ii)the placement or the expected placement of the child;
the employee would have a reasonable expectation of continuing employment by the employer on a regular and systematic basis.
Date at which employee must have completed 12 months of service
(3)For the purposes of subsections(1) and (2), the date that applies is:
(a)if the leave is:
(i)birth‑related leave starting before the birth of the child; or
(ii)unpaid special parentalleave;
the expected date of birth of the child; or
(b)in any other case—the date on which the employee’s period of leave is to start.
Meaning ofbirth‑related leave
(4)Birth‑related leavemeans leave of either of the following kinds:
(a)unpaid parental leave taken in association with the birth of a child (see section70);
(b)unpaid special parentalleave (see section80).
Meaning ofadoption‑related leave
(5)Adoption‑related leavemeans leave of either of the following kinds:
(a)unpaid parental leave taken in association with the placement of a child for adoption (see section70);
(b)unpaid pre‑adoption leave (see section85).
Meaning ofday of placement
(6)Theday of placement, in relation to the adoption of a child by an employee, means the earlier of the following days:
(a)the day on which the employee first takes custody of the child for the adoption;
(b)the day on which the employee starts any travel that is reasonably necessary to take custody of the child for the adoption.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s67/1.content: An employee, other than a casual employee, is not entitled to leave under this Division (other than unpaid pre‑adoption leave or unpaid no safe job leave)unless the employee has, or will have, completed at least 12 months of continuous service with the employer immediately before the date that applies under subsection(3). Employees other than casual employees (1A)For the purposes of applying subsection(1) in relation to an employee who has had their employment changed under Division4A of Part2‑2, any period for which the employee was a regular casual employee of the employer is taken to be continuous service for the purposes of that subsection. Casual employees

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s67/2.content: A casual employee, is not entitled to leave (other than unpaid pre‑adoption leave or unpaid no safe job leave) under this Division unless:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s67/2/a.content: the employee is, or will be, immediately before the date that applies under subsection(3), a regular casual employee of the employer who has been employed on that basis for a sequence of periods of employment during a period of at least 12 months; and

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s67/2/i.content: the birth or expected birth of the child; or

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s67/2/ii.content: the placement or the expected placement of the child; the employee would have a reasonable expectation of continuing employment by the employer on a regular and systematic basis. Date at which employee must have completed 12 months of service

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s67/3.content: For the purposes of subsections(1) and (2), the date that applies is:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s67/3/i.content: birth‑related leave starting before the birth of the child; or

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s67/3/ii.content: unpaid special parentalleave; the expected date of birth of the child; or

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s67/3/b.content: in any other case—the date on which the employee’s period of leave is to start. Meaning ofbirth‑related leave

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s67/4.content: Birth‑related leavemeans leave of either of the following kinds:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s67/4/a.content: unpaid parental leave taken in association with the birth of a child (see section70);

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s67/4/b.content: unpaid special parentalleave (see section80). Meaning ofadoption‑related leave

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s67/5.content: Adoption‑related leavemeans leave of either of the following kinds:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s67/5/a.content: unpaid parental leave taken in association with the placement of a child for adoption (see section70);

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s67/5/b.content: unpaid pre‑adoption leave (see section85). Meaning ofday of placement

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s67/6.content: Theday of placement, in relation to the adoption of a child by an employee, means the earlier of the following days:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s67/6/a.content: the day on which the employee first takes custody of the child for the adoption;

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s67/6/b.content: the day on which the employee starts any travel that is reasonably necessary to take custody of the child for the adoption.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s68.title: General rule for adoption‑related leave—child must be under 16 etc.
/au-federal/fwa/2009/s68.content:
An employee is not entitled to adoption‑related leave unless the child that is, or is to be, placed with the employee for adoption:
(a)is, or will be, under 16 as at the day of placement, or the expected day of placement, of the child; and
(b)has not, or will not have, lived continuously with the employee for a period of 6 months or more as at the day of placement, or the expected day of placement, of the child; and
(c)is not (otherwise than because of the adoption)a child of the employee or the employee’s spouse ordefactopartner.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s68/a.content: is, or will be, under 16 as at the day of placement, or the expected day of placement, of the child; and An employee is not entitled to adoption‑related leave unless the child that is, or is to be, placed with the employee for adoption:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s68/b.content: has not, or will not have, lived continuously with the employee for a period of 6 months or more as at the day of placement, or the expected day of placement, of the child; and

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s68/c.content: is not (otherwise than because of the adoption)a child of the employee or the employee’s spouse ordefactopartner.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s69.title: Transfer of employment situations in which employee is entitled to continue on leave etc.
/au-federal/fwa/2009/s69.content:
(1)If:
(a)there is a transfer of employment in relation to an employee; and
(b)the employee has already started a period of leave under this Division when the employee’s employment with the first employer ends;
the employee is entitled to continue on that leave for the rest of that period.
(2)If:
(a)there is a transfer of employment in relation to an employee; and
(b)the employee has, in relation to the first employer, already taken a step that is required or permitted by a provision of this Division in relation to taking a period of leave;
the employee is taken to have taken the step in relation to the second employer.
Subdivision B—Parental leave

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s69/1/a.content: there is a transfer of employment in relation to an employee; and

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s69/1/b.content: the employee has already started a period of leave under this Division when the employee’s employment with the first employer ends; the employee is entitled to continue on that leave for the rest of that period.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s69/2/a.content: there is a transfer of employment in relation to an employee; and

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s69/2/b.content: the employee has, in relation to the first employer, already taken a step that is required or permitted by a provision of this Division in relation to taking a period of leave; the employee is taken to have taken the step in relation to the second employer. Subdivision B—Parental leave

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s70.title: Entitlement to unpaid parental leave
/au-federal/fwa/2009/s70.content:
An employee is entitled to 12 months of unpaid parental leave if:
(a)the leave is associated with:
(i)the birth of a child of the employee or the employee’s spouse ordefactopartner; or
(ii)the placement of a child with the employee for adoption; and
(b)the employee has or will have a responsibility for the care of the child.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s70/a.content: the leave is associated with: An employee is entitled to 12 months of unpaid parental leave if:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s70/i.content: the birth of a child of the employee or the employee’s spouse ordefactopartner; or

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s70/ii.content: the placement of a child with the employee for adoption; and

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s70/b.content: the employee has or will have a responsibility for the care of the child.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s71.title: The period of leave
/au-federal/fwa/2009/s71.content:
Application of this section
(1)This section applies to an employee who intends to take unpaid parental leave.
Leave must be taken in single continuous period
(2)The employee must take the leave in a single continuous period.
When birth‑related leave must start and end
(3)If the leave is birth‑related leave for an employee who is pregnant with, or gives birth to, the child, the period of leave may start:
(a)up to 6 weeks before the expected date of birth of the child; or
(b)earlier, if the employer and employee so agree; or
(c)during the 24‑month period starting on the date of birth of the child;
but must end during the 24‑month period starting on the date of birth of the child.
(4)If the leave is birth‑related leave but subsection(3) does not apply, the period of leave must start and end during the 24‑month period starting on the date of birth of the child.
When adoption‑related leave must start and end
(5)If the leave is adoption‑related leave, the period of leave must start and end during the 24‑month period starting on the day of placement of the child.
Limit on amount of leave
(6)The employee may take unpaid parental leave under this section only if the period of leave is no longer than 12 months, less the employee’s notional flexible period.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s71/1.content: This section applies to an employee who intends to take unpaid parental leave. Application of this section Leave must be taken in single continuous period

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s71/2.content: The employee must take the leave in a single continuous period. When birth‑related leave must start and end

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s71/3.content: If the leave is birth‑related leave for an employee who is pregnant with, or gives birth to, the child, the period of leave may start:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s71/3/a.content: up to 6 weeks before the expected date of birth of the child; or

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s71/3/b.content: earlier, if the employer and employee so agree; or

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s71/3/c.content: during the 24‑month period starting on the date of birth of the child; but must end during the 24‑month period starting on the date of birth of the child.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s71/4.content: If the leave is birth‑related leave but subsection(3) does not apply, the period of leave must start and end during the 24‑month period starting on the date of birth of the child. When adoption‑related leave must start and end

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s71/5.content: If the leave is adoption‑related leave, the period of leave must start and end during the 24‑month period starting on the day of placement of the child. Limit on amount of leave

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s71/6.content: The employee may take unpaid parental leave under this section only if the period of leave is no longer than 12 months, less the employee’s notional flexible period.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s72A.title: Flexible unpaid parental leave
/au-federal/fwa/2009/s72A.content:
Taking leave during 24 months starting on date of birth or day of placement
(1)An employee may take up to 100 days (or, if a higher number of days is prescribed by the regulations, that higher number of days) of unpaid parental leave (flexible unpaid parental leave) during the 24‑month period starting on the date of birth or day of placement of the child if the requirements of this section are satisfied in relation to the leave.
(2)Flexible unpaid parental leave under subsection(1) is available in full to part‑time and casual employees.
Taking leave that starts up to 6 weeks before the expected date of birth of the child
(2A)A pregnant employee may take unpaid parental leave (flexible unpaid parental leave) during the period that starts 6 weeks before the expected date of birth of the child if the requirements of this section are satisfied in relation to the leave.
(2B)Flexible unpaid parental leave under subsection(2A) is available in full to pregnant part‑time employees and pregnant casual employees.
(2C)The amount of flexible unpaid parental leave to which an employee is entitled under subsection(1) in relation to the child is reduced by the number of days of flexible unpaid parental leave taken by the employee under subsection(2A) in relation to the child.
How flexible unpaid parental leave may be taken
(3)The employee must take the flexible unpaid parental leave as:
(a)a single continuous period of one or more days; or
(b)separate periods of one or more days each.
Effect of taking unpaid parental leave under other provisions
(4)The employee may take the flexible unpaid parental leave whether or not the employee has taken unpaid parental leave under another provision of this Division in relation to the child.
(5)However, the employee may take flexible unpaid parental leave after taking one or more periods of unpaid parental leave under another provision of this Division only if the total of those periods (disregarding any extension under section76A) is no longer than 12 months, less the employee’s notional flexible period.
Meaning ofnotional flexible period
(6)An employee’snotional flexibleperiodis the period during which the employee would be on flexible unpaid parental leave if the employee took leave for all the employee’s flexible days in a single continuous period. For this purpose, the employee’s flexible days are the flexible days notified to the employer under subsection74(3C) (subject to any agreement under subsection74(3D)).
(7)For the purposes of subsection(6), assume that:
(a)the employee ordinarily works each day that is not a Saturday or a Sunday; and
(b)there are no public holidays during the period.
Multiple births
(10)An employee is not entitled to take flexible unpaid parental leave in relation to a child if:
(a)the child and another child:
(i)are born during the same multiple birth; or
(ii)are both placed with the employee for adoption and have the same day of placement; and
(b)the employee takes flexible unpaid parental leave in relation to the other child.
Interaction with section71
(11)Flexible unpaid parental leave taken by an employee is an exception to the rules in section71 about:
(a)taking the employee’s unpaid parental leave in a single continuous period; and
(b)when the employee’s period of unpaid parental leave must start.
(12)Despite anything in subsection(11), flexible unpaid parental leave cannot be used to break up a period of unpaid parental leave taken under section71.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s72A/1.content: An employee may take up to 100 days (or, if a higher number of days is prescribed by the regulations, that higher number of days) of unpaid parental leave (flexible unpaid parental leave) during the 24‑month period starting on the date of birth or day of placement of the child if the requirements of this section are satisfied in relation to the leave. Taking leave during 24 months starting on date of birth or day of placement

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s72A/2.content: Flexible unpaid parental leave under subsection(1) is available in full to part‑time and casual employees. Taking leave that starts up to 6 weeks before the expected date of birth of the child (2A)A pregnant employee may take unpaid parental leave (flexible unpaid parental leave) during the period that starts 6 weeks before the expected date of birth of the child if the requirements of this section are satisfied in relation to the leave. (2B)Flexible unpaid parental leave under subsection(2A) is available in full to pregnant part‑time employees and pregnant casual employees. (2C)The amount of flexible unpaid parental leave to which an employee is entitled under subsection(1) in relation to the child is reduced by the number of days of flexible unpaid parental leave taken by the employee under subsection(2A) in relation to the child. How flexible unpaid parental leave may be taken

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s72A/3.content: The employee must take the flexible unpaid parental leave as:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s72A/3/a.content: a single continuous period of one or more days; or

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s72A/3/b.content: separate periods of one or more days each. Effect of taking unpaid parental leave under other provisions

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s72A/4.content: The employee may take the flexible unpaid parental leave whether or not the employee has taken unpaid parental leave under another provision of this Division in relation to the child.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s72A/5.content: However, the employee may take flexible unpaid parental leave after taking one or more periods of unpaid parental leave under another provision of this Division only if the total of those periods (disregarding any extension under section76A) is no longer than 12 months, less the employee’s notional flexible period. Meaning ofnotional flexible period

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s72A/6.content: An employee’snotional flexibleperiodis the period during which the employee would be on flexible unpaid parental leave if the employee took leave for all the employee’s flexible days in a single continuous period. For this purpose, the employee’s flexible days are the flexible days notified to the employer under subsection74(3C) (subject to any agreement under subsection74(3D)).

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s72A/7.content: For the purposes of subsection(6), assume that:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s72A/7/a.content: the employee ordinarily works each day that is not a Saturday or a Sunday; and

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s72A/7/b.content: there are no public holidays during the period. Multiple births

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s72A/10.content: An employee is not entitled to take flexible unpaid parental leave in relation to a child if:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s72A/10/i.content: are born during the same multiple birth; or

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s72A/10/ii.content: are both placed with the employee for adoption and have the same day of placement; and

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s72A/10/b.content: the employee takes flexible unpaid parental leave in relation to the other child. Interaction with section71

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s72A/11.content: Flexible unpaid parental leave taken by an employee is an exception to the rules in section71 about:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s72A/11/a.content: taking the employee’s unpaid parental leave in a single continuous period; and

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s72A/11/b.content: when the employee’s period of unpaid parental leave must start.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s72A/12.content: Despite anything in subsection(11), flexible unpaid parental leave cannot be used to break up a period of unpaid parental leave taken under section71.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s73.title: Pregnant employee may be required to take unpaid parental leave within 6 weeks before the birth
/au-federal/fwa/2009/s73.content:
Employer may ask employee to provide a medical certificate
(1)If a pregnant employee who is entitled to unpaid parental leave (whether or not the employee has complied with section74) continues to work during the 6 week period before the expected date of birth of the child, the employer may ask the employee to give the employer a medical certificate containing the following statements (as applicable):
(a)a statement of whether the employee is fit for work;
(b)if the employee is fit for work—a statement of whether it is inadvisable for the employee to continue in the employee’s present position during a stated period because of:
(i)illness, or risks, arising out of the employee’s pregnancy; or
(ii)hazards connected with the position.
Employer may require employee to take unpaid parental leave
(2)The employer may require the employee to take a period of unpaid parental leave other than flexible unpaid parental leave (theperiod of leave) as soon as practicable if:
(a)the employee does not give the employer the requested certificate within 7 days after the request; or
(b)within 7 days after the request, the employee gives the employer a medical certificate stating that the employee is not fit for work; or
(c)the following subparagraphs are satisfied:
(i)within 7 days after the request, the employee gives the employer a medical certificate stating that the employee is fit for work, but that it is inadvisable for the employee to continue in the employee’s present position for a stated period for a reason referred to in subparagraph(1)(b)(i) or (ii);
(ii)the employee has not complied with the notice and evidence requirements of section74 for taking unpaid parental leave.
When the period of leave must end
(3)The period of leave must not end later than the earlier of the following:
(a)the end of the pregnancy;
(b)if the employee has given the employer notice of the taking of a period of leave connected with the birth of the child (whether it is unpaid parental leave or some other kind of leave)—the start date of that leave.
Special rules about the period of leave
(4)The period of leave is an exception to the rules in section71 about:
(a)taking the employee’s unpaid parental leave in a single continuous period; and
(b)when the employee’s period of unpaid parental leave must start.
(5)The employee is not required to comply with section74 in relation to the period of leave.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s73/1.content: If a pregnant employee who is entitled to unpaid parental leave (whether or not the employee has complied with section74) continues to work during the 6 week period before the expected date of birth of the child, the employer may ask the employee to give the employer a medical certificate containing the following statements (as applicable): Employer may ask employee to provide a medical certificate

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s73/1/a.content: a statement of whether the employee is fit for work;

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s73/1/b.content: if the employee is fit for work—a statement of whether it is inadvisable for the employee to continue in the employee’s present position during a stated period because of:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s73/1/i.content: illness, or risks, arising out of the employee’s pregnancy; or

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s73/1/ii.content: hazards connected with the position. Employer may require employee to take unpaid parental leave

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s73/2.content: The employer may require the employee to take a period of unpaid parental leave other than flexible unpaid parental leave (theperiod of leave) as soon as practicable if:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s73/2/a.content: the employee does not give the employer the requested certificate within 7 days after the request; or

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s73/2/b.content: within 7 days after the request, the employee gives the employer a medical certificate stating that the employee is not fit for work; or

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s73/2/i.content: within 7 days after the request, the employee gives the employer a medical certificate stating that the employee is fit for work, but that it is inadvisable for the employee to continue in the employee’s present position for a stated period for a reason referred to in subparagraph(1)(b)(i) or (ii);
