References to instruments

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s113/7.content: References in this section to a kind of instrument (other than an enterprise agreement) are references to a transitional instrument of that kind, as continued in existence by Schedule3 to the Transitional Act.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s113A.title: Enterprise agreements may contain terms discounting service under prior agreements etc. in certain circumstances

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s113A/1/a.content: an instrument (thefirst instrument) of one of the following kinds that came into operation before the commencement of this Part applies to an employee on or after the commencement of this Part:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s113A/1/b.content: the instrument states that the employee is not entitled to long service leave; and

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s113A/1/c.content: the instrument ceases, for whatever reason, to apply to the employee; and

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s113A/1/d.content: immediately after the first instrument ceases to apply, an enterprise agreement (thereplacement agreement) starts to apply to the employee.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s113A/2.content: The replacement agreementmay include terms to the effect that an employee’s service with the employer during a specified period (theexcluded period) (being some or all of the period when the first instrument applied to the employee) does not count as service for the purpose of determining whether the employee is qualified for long service leave, or the amount of long service leave to which the employee is entitled, under this Division or under a law of a State or Territory.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s113A/3.content: If the replacement agreement includes terms as permitted by subsection(2), the excluded period does not count, and never again counts, as service for the purpose of determining whether the employee is qualified for long service leave, or the amount of long service leave to which the employee is entitled, under this Division or under a law of a State or Territory, unless a later agreement provides otherwise. This subsection has effect despite sections27 and 29.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s113A/4.content: References in this section to a kind of instrument (other than an enterprise agreement) are references to a transitional instrument of that kind, as continued in existence by Schedule3 to the Transitional Act.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s114.title: Entitlement to be absent from employment on public holiday

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s114/1.content: An employee is entitled to be absent from his or her employment on a day or part‑day that is a public holiday in the place where the employee is based for work purposes. Employee entitled to be absent on public holiday Reasonable requests to work on public holidays

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s114/2.content: However, an employer may request an employee to work on a public holiday if the request is reasonable.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s114/3.content: If an employer requests an employee to work on a public holiday, the employee may refuse the request if:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s114/3/a.content: the request is not reasonable; or

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s114/4.content: In determining whether a request, or a refusal of a request, to work on a public holiday is reasonable,the following must be taken into account:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s114/4/a.content: the nature of the employer’s workplace or enterprise (including its operational requirements), and the nature of the work performed by the employee;

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s114/4/b.content: the employee’s personal circumstances, including family responsibilities;

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s114/4/c.content: whether the employee could reasonably expect that the employer might request work on the public holiday;

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s114/4/d.content: whether the employee is entitled to receive overtime payments, penalty rates or other compensation for, or a level of remuneration that reflects an expectation of, work on the public holiday;

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s114/4/e.content: the type of employment of the employee (for example, whether full‑time, part‑time, casual or shiftwork);

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s114/4/f.content: the amount of notice in advance of the public holiday given by the employer when making the request;

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s114/4/g.content: in relation to the refusal of a request—the amount of notice in advance of the public holiday given by the employee when refusing the request;

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s115.title: Meaning ofpublic holiday

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s115/1.content: The following arepublic holidays: The public holidays

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s115/1/vi.content: the holiday for the birthday of the Sovereign (on the day on which it is celebrated in a State or Territory or a region of a State or Territory);

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s115/1/b.content: any other day, or part‑day, declared or prescribed by or under a law of a State or Territory to be observed generally within the State or Territory, or a region of the State or Territory, as a public holiday, other than a day or part‑day, or a kind of day or part‑day, that is excluded by the regulations from counting as a public holiday. Substituted public holidays under State or Territory laws

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s115/2.content: If, under (or in accordance with a procedure under) a law of a State or Territory, a day or part‑day is substituted for a day or part‑day that would otherwise be a public holiday because of subsection(1), then the substituted day or part‑day is thepublic holiday. Substituted public holidays under modern awards and enterprise agreements

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s115/3.content: A modern award or enterprise agreement may include terms providing for an employer and employee to agree on the substitution of a day or part‑day for a day or part‑day that would otherwise be a public holiday because of subsection(1) or (2). Substituted public holidays for award/agreement free employees

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s115/4.content: An employer and an award/agreement free employee may agree on the substitution of a day or part‑day for a day or part‑day that would otherwise be a public holiday because of subsection(1) or (2).

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s116.title: Payment for absence on public holiday
/au-federal/fwa/2009/s116.content:
If, in accordance with this Division, an employee is absent from his or her employment on a day or part‑day that is a public holiday, the employer must pay the employee at the employee’s base rate of pay forthe employee’s ordinary hours of work on the day or part‑day.
CollapseDivision 10A—Superannuation contributions

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s116A.title: Division does not apply to certain employees or employers in referring States
/au-federal/fwa/2009/s116A.content:
This Division does not apply in relation to:
(a)an employee who is a national system employee only because of section30C or 30M (which extend the meaning ofnational system employee); or
(b)an employer that is a national system employer only because of section30D or 30N (which extend the meaning ofnational system employer).

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s116A/a.content: an employee who is a national system employee only because of section30C or 30M (which extend the meaning ofnational system employee); or This Division does not apply in relation to:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s116A/b.content: an employer that is a national system employer only because of section30D or 30N (which extend the meaning ofnational system employer).

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s116B.title: Employer’s obligation to make superannuation contributions
/au-federal/fwa/2009/s116B.content: An employer must make contributions to a superannuation fund for the benefit of an employee so as to avoid liability to pay superannuation guarantee charge under theSuperannuation Guarantee Charge Act 1992in relation to the employee.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s116C.title: Reduction of employer’s liability to the extent of superannuation charge payments
/au-federal/fwa/2009/s116C.content:
The obligation to make contributions for an employee under section116B does not apply to an employer to the extent that:
(a)the employer has made a charge payment (within the meaning of section63A of theSuperannuation Guarantee (Administration) Act 1992) in respect of the employee under Part8 of that Act; and
(b)the employee is a benefiting employee (within the meaning of that Part); and
(c)the Commissioner of Taxation is required to pay, or otherwise deal with, a shortfall component (within the meaning of that Part) for the benefit of the employee under that Part.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s116C/a.content: the employer has made a charge payment (within the meaning of section63A of theSuperannuation Guarantee (Administration) Act 1992) in respect of the employee under Part8 of that Act; and The obligation to make contributions for an employee under section116B does not apply to an employer to the extent that:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s116C/b.content: the employee is a benefiting employee (within the meaning of that Part); and

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s116C/c.content: the Commissioner of Taxation is required to pay, or otherwise deal with, a shortfall component (within the meaning of that Part) for the benefit of the employee under that Part.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s116D.title: Preventing multiple actions
/au-federal/fwa/2009/s116D.content:
Scope
(1)This section applies if:
(a)an employer has contravened, or allegedly contravened, a civil remedy provision that relates to a contravention of this Division; and
(b)the contravention, or alleged contravention, relates wholly or partly to an employee; and
(c)the employee or another person referred to in an item in column 2 of the table in subsection539(2) would be entitled to apply for an order under Division2 of Part4‑1 in relation to the contravention, or alleged contravention.
No application for orders in certain circumstances
(2)An application for such an order may not be made if:
(a)the Commissioner of Taxation has commenced proceedings against the employer to recover an amount of superannuation guarantee charge; and
(b)either:
(i)the Commissioner has obtained an order for recovery of the charge; or
(ii)if the proceedings have not been finally disposed of—the Commissioner has not discontinued the proceedings; and
(c)the employer’s superannuation guarantee shortfall in respect of which the charge is imposed includes an individual superannuation guarantee shortfall for the employee.
(3)Terms (apart from employee and employer) used in this section that are defined in theSuperannuation Guarantee (Administration) Act 1992have the same meaning in this section as they have in that Act.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s116D/1/a.content: an employer has contravened, or allegedly contravened, a civil remedy provision that relates to a contravention of this Division; and

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s116D/1/b.content: the contravention, or alleged contravention, relates wholly or partly to an employee; and

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s116D/1/c.content: the employee or another person referred to in an item in column 2 of the table in subsection539(2) would be entitled to apply for an order under Division2 of Part4‑1 in relation to the contravention, or alleged contravention. No application for orders in certain circumstances

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s116D/2.content: An application for such an order may not be made if:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s116D/2/a.content: the Commissioner of Taxation has commenced proceedings against the employer to recover an amount of superannuation guarantee charge; and

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s116D/2/i.content: the Commissioner has obtained an order for recovery of the charge; or

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s116D/2/ii.content: if the proceedings have not been finally disposed of—the Commissioner has not discontinued the proceedings; and

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s116D/2/c.content: the employer’s superannuation guarantee shortfall in respect of which the charge is imposed includes an individual superannuation guarantee shortfall for the employee.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s116D/3.content: Terms (apart from employee and employer) used in this section that are defined in theSuperannuation Guarantee (Administration) Act 1992have the same meaning in this section as they have in that Act.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s116E.title: Orders for compensation
/au-federal/fwa/2009/s116E.content: Subdivision A—Notice of termination or payment in lieu of notice

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s116E/1.content: This section applies if a court makes an order under section545 awarding compensation to an employee for a contravention of a civil remedy provision that relates to a contravention of this Division.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s116E/2.content: The court must have regard to the principle that any component of the compensation payable on account of unpaid superannuation contributions should usually be paid to a superannuation fund for the benefit of the employee.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/part-2\u20112/div-1.title: Division 11—Notice of termination and redundancy pay

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s117.title: Requirement for notice of termination or payment in lieu
/au-federal/fwa/2009/s117.content:
Notice specifying day of termination
(1)An employer must not terminate an employee’s employment unless the employer has given the employee written notice of the day of the termination (which cannot be before the day the notice is given).
Amount of notice or payment in lieu of notice
(2)The employer must not terminate the employee’s employment unless:
(a)the time between giving the notice and the day of the termination is at least the period (theminimum period of notice) worked out under subsection(3); or
(b)the employer has paid to the employee (or to another person on the employee’s behalf) payment in lieu of notice of at least the amount the employer would have been liable to pay to the employee (or to another person on the employee’s behalf) at the full rate of pay for the hours the employee would have worked had the employment continued until the end of the minimum period of notice.
(3)Work out the minimum period of notice as follows:
(a)first, work out the period using the following table:
Employee’s period of continuous service with the employer at the end of the day the notice is given
Not more than 1 year
More than 1 year but not more than 3 years
More than 3 years but not more than 5 years
More than 5 years
(b)then increase the period by 1 week if the employee is over 45 years old and has completed at least 2 years of continuous service with the employer at the end of the day the notice is given.
(4)A reference in this section to continuous service with the employer does not include periods of employment as a casual employee of the employer.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s117/1.content: An employer must not terminate an employee’s employment unless the employer has given the employee written notice of the day of the termination (which cannot be before the day the notice is given). Notice specifying day of termination Amount of notice or payment in lieu of notice

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s117/2.content: The employer must not terminate the employee’s employment unless:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s117/2/a.content: the time between giving the notice and the day of the termination is at least the period (theminimum period of notice) worked out under subsection(3); or

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s117/2/b.content: the employer has paid to the employee (or to another person on the employee’s behalf) payment in lieu of notice of at least the amount the employer would have been liable to pay to the employee (or to another person on the employee’s behalf) at the full rate of pay for the hours the employee would have worked had the employment continued until the end of the minimum period of notice.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s117/3.content: Work out the minimum period of notice as follows:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s117/3/a.content: first, work out the period using the following table: Employee’s period of continuous service with the employer at the end of the day the notice is given Not more than 1 year More than 1 year but not more than 3 years More than 3 years but not more than 5 years More than 5 years

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s117/3/b.content: then increase the period by 1 week if the employee is over 45 years old and has completed at least 2 years of continuous service with the employer at the end of the day the notice is given.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s117/4.content: A reference in this section to continuous service with the employer does not include periods of employment as a casual employee of the employer.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s118.title: Modern awards and enterprise agreements may provide for notice of termination by employees
/au-federal/fwa/2009/s118.content:
A modern award or enterprise agreement may include terms specifying the period of notice an employee must give in order to terminate his or her employment.
Subdivision B—Redundancy pay

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s119.title: Redundancy pay
/au-federal/fwa/2009/s119.content:
Entitlement to redundancy pay
(1)An employee is entitled to be paid redundancy pay by the employer if the employee’s employment is terminated:
(a)at the employer’s initiative because the employer no longer requires the job done by the employee to be done by anyone, except where this is due to the ordinary and customary turnover of labour; or
(b)because of the insolvency or bankruptcy of the employer.
Amount of redundancy pay
(2)The amount of the redundancy pay equals the total amount payable to the employee for the redundancy pay period worked out using the following table at the employee’s base rate of pay for his or her ordinary hours of work:
Redundancy pay period
Employee’s period of continuous service with the employer on termination
Redundancy pay period
At least 1 year but less than 2 years
At least 2 years but less than 3 years
At least 3 years but less than 4 years
At least 4 years but less than 5 years
At least 5 years but less than 6 years
At least 6 years but less than 7 years
At least 7 years but less than 8 years
At least 8 years but less than 9 years
At least 9 years but less than 10 years
At least 10 years
(3)A reference in this section to continuous service with the employer does not include periods of employment as a casual employee of the employer.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s119/1.content: An employee is entitled to be paid redundancy pay by the employer if the employee’s employment is terminated: Entitlement to redundancy pay

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s119/1/a.content: at the employer’s initiative because the employer no longer requires the job done by the employee to be done by anyone, except where this is due to the ordinary and customary turnover of labour; or

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s119/1/b.content: because of the insolvency or bankruptcy of the employer. Amount of redundancy pay

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s119/2.content: The amount of the redundancy pay equals the total amount payable to the employee for the redundancy pay period worked out using the following table at the employee’s base rate of pay for his or her ordinary hours of work: Redundancy pay period Employee’s period of continuous service with the employer on termination Redundancy pay period At least 1 year but less than 2 years At least 2 years but less than 3 years At least 3 years but less than 4 years At least 4 years but less than 5 years At least 5 years but less than 6 years At least 6 years but less than 7 years At least 7 years but less than 8 years At least 8 years but less than 9 years At least 9 years but less than 10 years At least 10 years

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s119/3.content: A reference in this section to continuous service with the employer does not include periods of employment as a casual employee of the employer.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s120.title: Variation of redundancy pay for other employment or incapacity to pay
/au-federal/fwa/2009/s120.content:
(1)This section applies if:
(a)an employee is entitled to be paid an amount of redundancy pay by the employer because of section119; and
(b)the employer:
(i)obtains other acceptable employment for the employee; or
(ii)cannot pay the amount.
(2)On application by the employer, the FWC may determine that the amount of redundancy pay is reduced to a specified amount (which may be nil) that the FWC considers appropriate.
(3)The amount of redundancy pay to which the employee is entitled under section119 is the reduced amount specified in the determination.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s120/1/a.content: an employee is entitled to be paid an amount of redundancy pay by the employer because of section119; and

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s120/1/i.content: obtains other acceptable employment for the employee; or

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s120/2.content: On application by the employer, the FWC may determine that the amount of redundancy pay is reduced to a specified amount (which may be nil) that the FWC considers appropriate.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s120/3.content: The amount of redundancy pay to which the employee is entitled under section119 is the reduced amount specified in the determination.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s121.title: Exclusions from obligation to pay redundancy pay
/au-federal/fwa/2009/s121.content:
(1)Section119 does not apply to the termination of an employee’s employment if, immediately before the time of the termination, or at the time when the person was given notice of the termination as described in subsection117(1) (whichever happened first):
(a)the employee’s period of continuous service with the employer (other than periods of employment as a casual employee of the employer) is less than 12 months; or
(b)the employer is a small business employer.
(2)A modern award may include a term specifying other situations in which section119 does not apply to the termination of an employee’s employment.
(3)If a modern award that is in operation includes such a term (theaward term), an enterprise agreement may:
(a)incorporate the award term by reference (and as in force from time to time) into the enterprise agreement; and
(b)provide that the incorporated term covers some or all of the employees who are also covered by the award term.
Certain small businesses to pay redundancy pay
(4)Despite subsection(1), an employee whose employment is terminated is entitled to be paid redundancy pay in accordance with this Division if:
(a)at the time of the termination, section119 did not apply to the termination because the employer was a small business employer; and
(b)the employer is bankrupt or in liquidation (other than only because of a members’ voluntary winding up); and
(c)the employer is a small business employer because the employment of one or more employees was terminated; and
(d)those terminations occurred:
(i)on or after the day that is 6 months before the employer became bankrupt or went into liquidation; or
(ii)if there was an insolvency practitioner (thelast insolvency practitioner) for the employer on the business day before the employer became bankrupt or went into liquidation—on or after the day that is 6 months before the insolvency practitioner was appointed; or
(iii)if, before the last insolvency practitioner was appointed, other insolvency practitioners for the employer were appointed without any intervening business days between any of those appointments—on or after the day that is 6 months before the first of those insolvency practitioners was appointed; or
(iv)due to the insolvency of the employer.
(5)Amembers’ voluntary winding upis a winding up under section495 of theCorporations Act 2001.
Time of liquidation—members’ voluntary winding up where company turns out to be insolvent
(6)If a liquidator takes action under section496 of theCorporations Act 2001(company turns out to be insolvent) in relation to a small business employer whose liquidation began as a members’ voluntary winding up, then, for the purposes of subparagraph(4)(d)(i), the time the employer goes into liquidation is the time the employer goes into liquidation because of the members’ voluntary winding up.
Application to partnerships
(7)For the purposes of subsection(4), a small business employer that is a partnership is not bankrupt or in liquidation unless each partner of the partnership is bankrupt or in liquidation, as the case requires.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s121/1.content: Section119 does not apply to the termination of an employee’s employment if, immediately before the time of the termination, or at the time when the person was given notice of the termination as described in subsection117(1) (whichever happened first):

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s121/1/a.content: the employee’s period of continuous service with the employer (other than periods of employment as a casual employee of the employer) is less than 12 months; or

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s121/1/b.content: the employer is a small business employer.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s121/2.content: A modern award may include a term specifying other situations in which section119 does not apply to the termination of an employee’s employment.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s121/3.content: If a modern award that is in operation includes such a term (theaward term), an enterprise agreement may:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s121/3/a.content: incorporate the award term by reference (and as in force from time to time) into the enterprise agreement; and

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s121/3/b.content: provide that the incorporated term covers some or all of the employees who are also covered by the award term. Certain small businesses to pay redundancy pay

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s121/4.content: Despite subsection(1), an employee whose employment is terminated is entitled to be paid redundancy pay in accordance with this Division if:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s121/4/a.content: at the time of the termination, section119 did not apply to the termination because the employer was a small business employer; and

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s121/4/b.content: the employer is bankrupt or in liquidation (other than only because of a members’ voluntary winding up); and

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s121/4/c.content: the employer is a small business employer because the employment of one or more employees was terminated; and

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s121/4/i.content: on or after the day that is 6 months before the employer became bankrupt or went into liquidation; or

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s121/4/ii.content: if there was an insolvency practitioner (thelast insolvency practitioner) for the employer on the business day before the employer became bankrupt or went into liquidation—on or after the day that is 6 months before the insolvency practitioner was appointed; or

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s121/4/iii.content: if, before the last insolvency practitioner was appointed, other insolvency practitioners for the employer were appointed without any intervening business days between any of those appointments—on or after the day that is 6 months before the first of those insolvency practitioners was appointed; or

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s121/4/iv.content: due to the insolvency of the employer.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s121/5.content: Amembers’ voluntary winding upis a winding up under section495 of theCorporations Act 2001. Time of liquidation—members’ voluntary winding up where company turns out to be insolvent

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s121/6.content: If a liquidator takes action under section496 of theCorporations Act 2001(company turns out to be insolvent) in relation to a small business employer whose liquidation began as a members’ voluntary winding up, then, for the purposes of subparagraph(4)(d)(i), the time the employer goes into liquidation is the time the employer goes into liquidation because of the members’ voluntary winding up. Application to partnerships

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s121/7.content: For the purposes of subsection(4), a small business employer that is a partnership is not bankrupt or in liquidation unless each partner of the partnership is bankrupt or in liquidation, as the case requires.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s122.title: Transfer of employment situations that affect the obligation to pay redundancy pay
/au-federal/fwa/2009/s122.content:
Transfer of employment situation in which employer may decide not to recognise employee’s service with first employer
(1)Subsection22(5) does not apply (for the purpose of this Subdivision) to a transfer of employment between non‑associated entities in relation to an employee if the second employer decides not to recognise the employee’s service with the first employer (for the purpose of this Subdivision).
Employee is not entitled to redundancy pay if service with first employer counts as service with second employer
(2)If subsection22(5) applies (for the purpose of this Subdivision) to a transfer of employment in relation to an employee, the employee is not entitled to redundancy pay under section119 in relation to the termination of his or her employment with the first employer.
Employee not entitled to redundancy pay if refuses employment in certain circumstances
(3)An employee is not entitled to redundancy pay under section119 in relation to the termination of his or her employment with an employer (thefirst employer) if:
(a)the employee rejects an offer of employment made by another employer (thesecond employer) that:
(i)is on terms and conditions substantially similar to, and, considered on an overall basis, no less favourable than, the employee’s terms and conditions of employment with the first employer immediately before the termination; and
(ii)recognises the employee’s service with the first employer, for the purpose of this Subdivision; and
(b)had the employee accepted the offer, there would have been a transfer of employment in relation to the employee.
(4)If the FWC is satisfied that subsection(3) operates unfairly to the employee, the FWC may order the first employer to pay the employee a specified amount of redundancy pay (not exceeding the amount that would be payable but for subsection(3)) that the FWC considers appropriate. The first employer must pay the employee that amount of redundancy pay.
Subdivision C—Limits on scope of this Division

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s122/1.content: Subsection22(5) does not apply (for the purpose of this Subdivision) to a transfer of employment between non‑associated entities in relation to an employee if the second employer decides not to recognise the employee’s service with the first employer (for the purpose of this Subdivision). Transfer of employment situation in which employer may decide not to recognise employee’s service with first employer Employee is not entitled to redundancy pay if service with first employer counts as service with second employer

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s122/2.content: If subsection22(5) applies (for the purpose of this Subdivision) to a transfer of employment in relation to an employee, the employee is not entitled to redundancy pay under section119 in relation to the termination of his or her employment with the first employer. Employee not entitled to redundancy pay if refuses employment in certain circumstances

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s122/3.content: An employee is not entitled to redundancy pay under section119 in relation to the termination of his or her employment with an employer (thefirst employer) if:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s122/3/a.content: the employee rejects an offer of employment made by another employer (thesecond employer) that:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s122/3/i.content: is on terms and conditions substantially similar to, and, considered on an overall basis, no less favourable than, the employee’s terms and conditions of employment with the first employer immediately before the termination; and

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s122/3/ii.content: recognises the employee’s service with the first employer, for the purpose of this Subdivision; and

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s122/3/b.content: had the employee accepted the offer, there would have been a transfer of employment in relation to the employee.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s122/4.content: If the FWC is satisfied that subsection(3) operates unfairly to the employee, the FWC may order the first employer to pay the employee a specified amount of redundancy pay (not exceeding the amount that would be payable but for subsection(3)) that the FWC considers appropriate. The first employer must pay the employee that amount of redundancy pay. Subdivision C—Limits on scope of this Division

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s123.title: Limits on scope of this Division
/au-federal/fwa/2009/s123.content:
Employees not covered by this Division
(1)This Division does not apply to any of the following employees:
(a)an employee employed for a specified period of time, for a specified task, or for the duration of a specified season;
(b)an employee whose employment is terminated because of serious misconduct;
(c)a casual employee;
(d)an employee (other than an apprentice) to whom a training arrangement applies and whose employment is for a specified period of time or is, for any reason, limited to the duration of the training arrangement;
(e)an employee prescribed by the regulations as an employee to whom this Division does not apply.
(2)Paragraph(1)(a) does not prevent this Division from applying to an employee if a substantial reason for employing the employee as described in that paragraph was to avoid the application of this Division.
Other employees not covered by notice of termination provisions
(3)Subdivision A does not apply to:
(b)a daily hire employee working in the building and construction industry (including working in connection with the erection, repair, renovation, maintenance, ornamentation or demolition of buildings or structures); or
(c)a daily hire employee working in the meat industry in connection with the slaughter of livestock; or
(d)a weekly hire employee working in connection with the meat industry and whose termination of employment is determined solely by seasonal factors; or
(e)an employee prescribed by the regulations as an employee to whom that Subdivision does not apply.
Other employees not covered by redundancy pay provisions
(4)Subdivision B does not apply to:
(a)an employee who is an apprentice; or
(b)an employee to whom an industry‑specific redundancy scheme in a modern award applies; or
(c)an employee to whom a redundancy scheme in an enterprise agreement applies if:
(i)the scheme is an industry‑specific redundancy scheme that is incorporated by reference (and as in force from time to time) into the enterprise agreement from a modern award that is in operation; and
(ii)the employee is covered by the industry‑specific redundancy scheme in the modern award; or
(d)an employee prescribed by the regulations as an employee to whom that Subdivision does not apply.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s123/1.content: This Division does not apply to any of the following employees: Employees not covered by this Division

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s123/1/a.content: an employee employed for a specified period of time, for a specified task, or for the duration of a specified season;

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s123/1/b.content: an employee whose employment is terminated because of serious misconduct;

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s123/1/d.content: an employee (other than an apprentice) to whom a training arrangement applies and whose employment is for a specified period of time or is, for any reason, limited to the duration of the training arrangement;

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s123/1/e.content: an employee prescribed by the regulations as an employee to whom this Division does not apply.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s123/2.content: Paragraph(1)(a) does not prevent this Division from applying to an employee if a substantial reason for employing the employee as described in that paragraph was to avoid the application of this Division. Other employees not covered by notice of termination provisions

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s123/3.content: Subdivision A does not apply to:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s123/3/b.content: a daily hire employee working in the building and construction industry (including working in connection with the erection, repair, renovation, maintenance, ornamentation or demolition of buildings or structures); or

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s123/3/c.content: a daily hire employee working in the meat industry in connection with the slaughter of livestock; or

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s123/3/d.content: a weekly hire employee working in connection with the meat industry and whose termination of employment is determined solely by seasonal factors; or

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s123/3/e.content: an employee prescribed by the regulations as an employee to whom that Subdivision does not apply. Other employees not covered by redundancy pay provisions

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s123/4/a.content: an employee who is an apprentice; or

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s123/4/b.content: an employee to whom an industry‑specific redundancy scheme in a modern award applies; or

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s123/4/c.content: an employee to whom a redundancy scheme in an enterprise agreement applies if:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s123/4/i.content: the scheme is an industry‑specific redundancy scheme that is incorporated by reference (and as in force from time to time) into the enterprise agreement from a modern award that is in operation; and

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s123/4/ii.content: the employee is covered by the industry‑specific redundancy scheme in the modern award; or

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s123/4/d.content: an employee prescribed by the regulations as an employee to whom that Subdivision does not apply.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/part-2\u20112/div-1.title: Division 12—Fair Work Ombudsman to prepare and publish statements

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s124.title: Fair Work Ombudsman to prepare and publish Fair Work Information Statement

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s124/1.content: The Fair Work Ombudsman must prepare aFair Work Information Statement. The Fair Work Ombudsman must publish the Statement in theGazette.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s124/2.content: The Statement must contain information about the following:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s124/2/d.content: the right to freedom of association;

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s124/2/e.content: the role of the FWC and the Fair Work Ombudsman;

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s124/2/h.content: right of entry (including the protection of personal information by privacy laws).

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s124/3.content: The Fair Work Information Statement is not a legislative instrument.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s124/4.content: The regulations may prescribe other matters relating to the content or form of the Statement, or the manner in which employers may give the Statement to employees.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s125.title: Giving new employees the Fair Work Information Statement
/au-federal/fwa/2009/s125.content:
(1)An employer must give each employee the Fair Work Information Statement before, or as soon as practicable after, the employee starts employment.
(2)Subsection(1) does not require the employer to give the employee the Statement more than once in any 12 months.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s125/1.content: An employer must give each employee the Fair Work Information Statement before, or as soon as practicable after, the employee starts employment.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s125/2.content: Subsection(1) does not require the employer to give the employee the Statement more than once in any 12 months.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s125A.title: Fair Work Ombudsman to prepare and publish Casual Employment Information Statement

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s125A/1.content: The Fair Work Ombudsman must prepare a Casual Employment Information Statement. The Fair Work Ombudsman must publish the Statement in the Gazette.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s125A/2.content: The Statement must contain information about casual employment and how this can be changed under Division4A of Part2‑2, including the following:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s125A/2/a.content: the meaning of casual employee under section15A;

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s125A/2/aa.content: an employee who has completed 6 months of employment (12 months if a small business employer) can notify the employer if, having regard to the employee’s current employment relationship with the employer, the employeebelieves that the employee no longer meets the requirements of subsections15A(1) to (4);

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s125A/2/ab.content: the grounds upon which an employer may not accept a notification given by an employee;

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s125A/2/e.content: the FWC may deal with disputes about the operation of that Division.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s125A/3.content: The Casual Employment Information Statement is not a legislative instrument.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s125A/4.content: The regulations may prescribe other matters relating to the content or form of the Statement, or the manner in which employers may give the Statement to employees.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s125B.title: Giving employees the Casual Employment Information Statement
/au-federal/fwa/2009/s125B.content:
(1)An employer must give a casual employee the Casual Employment Information Statement:
(a)before, or as soon as practicable after, the employee starts employment as a casual employee with the employer; and
(b)as soon as practicable after the employee has been employed by the employer for a period of 6 months beginning the day the employment started; and
(c)as soon as practicable after the following:
(i)the employee has been employed by the employer for a period of 12 months beginning the day the employment started;
(ii)the end of any subsequent period of 12 months for which the employee is employed by the employer.
(2)However, paragraph(1)(b) and subparagraph(1)(c)(ii) do not apply if at the time the employer has employed the employee for the period referred to in that paragraph or subparagraph, the employer is a small business employer.
(3)This section does not, apart from the operation of paragraph(1)(b), require the employer to give the employee the Statement more than once in any 12 months.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s125B/1.content: An employer must give a casual employee the Casual Employment Information Statement:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s125B/1/a.content: before, or as soon as practicable after, the employee starts employment as a casual employee with the employer; and

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s125B/1/b.content: as soon as practicable after the employee has been employed by the employer for a period of 6 months beginning the day the employment started; and

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s125B/1/c.content: as soon as practicable after the following:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s125B/1/i.content: the employee has been employed by the employer for a period of 12 months beginning the day the employment started;

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s125B/1/ii.content: the end of any subsequent period of 12 months for which the employee is employed by the employer.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s125B/2.content: However, paragraph(1)(b) and subparagraph(1)(c)(ii) do not apply if at the time the employer has employed the employee for the period referred to in that paragraph or subparagraph, the employer is a small business employer.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s125B/3.content: This section does not, apart from the operation of paragraph(1)(b), require the employer to give the employee the Statement more than once in any 12 months.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s126.title: Modern awards and enterprise agreements may provide for school‑based apprentices and trainees to be paid loadings in lieu

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s126/a.content: paid annual leave; A modern award or enterprise agreement may provide for school‑based apprentices or school‑based trainees to be paid loadings in lieu of any of the following:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s126/c.content: paid absence under Division10 (which deals with public holidays). Note:Section199 affects whether the FWC may approve an enterprise agreement covering an employee who is a school‑based apprentice or school‑based trainee, if the employee is covered by a modern award that is in operation and provides for the employee to be paid loadings in lieu of paid annual leave, paid personal/carer’s leave or paid absence under Division10.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s127.title: Regulations about what modern awards and enterprise agreements can do
/au-federal/fwa/2009/s127.content:
The regulations may:
(a)permit modern awards or enterprise agreements or both to include terms that would or might otherwise be contrary to this Part or section55 (which deals with the interaction between the National Employment Standards and a modern award or enterprise agreement); or
(b)prohibit modern awards or enterprise agreements or both from including terms that would or might otherwise be permitted by a provision of this Part or section55.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s127/a.content: permit modern awards or enterprise agreements or both to include terms that would or might otherwise be contrary to this Part or section55 (which deals with the interaction between the National Employment Standards and a modern award or enterprise agreement); or The regulations may:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s127/b.content: prohibit modern awards or enterprise agreements or both from including terms that would or might otherwise be permitted by a provision of this Part or section55.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s128.title: Relationship between National Employment Standards and agreements etc. permitted by this Part for award/agreement free employees
/au-federal/fwa/2009/s128.content:
The National Employment Standards have effect subject to:
(a)an agreement between an employer and an award/agreement free employee or a requirement made by an employer of an award/agreement free employee, that is expressly permitted by a provision of this Part; or
(b)an agreement between an employer and an award/agreement free employee that is expressly permitted by regulations made for the purpose of section129.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s128/a.content: an agreement between an employer and an award/agreement free employee or a requirement made by an employer of an award/agreement free employee, that is expressly permitted by a provision of this Part; or The National Employment Standards have effect subject to:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s128/b.content: an agreement between an employer and an award/agreement free employee that is expressly permitted by regulations made for the purpose of section129.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s129.title: Regulations about what can be agreed to etc. in relation to award/agreement free employees
/au-federal/fwa/2009/s129.content:
The regulations may:
(a)permit employers, and award/agreement free employees, to agree on matters that would or might otherwise be contrary to this Part; or
(b)prohibit employers and award/agreement free employees from agreeing on matters, or prohibit employers from making requirements of such employees, that would or might otherwise be permitted by a provision of this Part.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s129/a.content: permit employers, and award/agreement free employees, to agree on matters that would or might otherwise be contrary to this Part; or The regulations may:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s129/b.content: prohibit employers and award/agreement free employees from agreeing on matters, or prohibit employers from making requirements of such employees, that would or might otherwise be permitted by a provision of this Part.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s130.title: Restriction on taking or accruing leave or absence while receiving workers’ compensation
/au-federal/fwa/2009/s130.content:
(1)An employee is not entitled to take or accrue any leave or absence (whether paid or unpaid) under this Part during a period (acompensation period) when the employee is absent from work because of a personal illness, or a personal injury, for which the employee is receiving compensation payable under a law (acompensation law) of the Commonwealth, a State or a Territory that is about workers’ compensation.
(2)Subsection(1) does not prevent an employee from taking or accruing leave during a compensation period if the taking or accruing of the leave is permitted by a compensation law.
(3)Subsection(1) does not prevent an employee from taking unpaid parental leave during a compensation period.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s130/1.content: An employee is not entitled to take or accrue any leave or absence (whether paid or unpaid) under this Part during a period (acompensation period) when the employee is absent from work because of a personal illness, or a personal injury, for which the employee is receiving compensation payable under a law (acompensation law) of the Commonwealth, a State or a Territory that is about workers’ compensation.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s130/2.content: Subsection(1) does not prevent an employee from taking or accruing leave during a compensation period if the taking or accruing of the leave is permitted by a compensation law.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s130/3.content: Subsection(1) does not prevent an employee from taking unpaid parental leave during a compensation period.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s131.title: Relationship with other Commonwealth laws
/au-federal/fwa/2009/s131.content: This Part establishes minimum standards and so is intended to supplement, and not to override, entitlements under other laws of the Commonwealth.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s132.title: Guide to this Part
/au-federal/fwa/2009/s132.content:
This Part provides for the FWC to make, vary and revoke modern awards. Modern awards may set minimum terms and conditions for national system employees in particular industries or occupations. Modern awards can have terms that are ancillary or supplementary to the National Employment Standards (see Part2‑1).
Division2 provides for the modern awards objective. This requires the FWC to ensure that modern awards, together with the National Employment Standards, provide a fair and relevant minimum safety net of terms and conditions, taking into account certain social and economic factors. Division2 also contains special provisions about modern award minimum wages.
Division3 deals with the terms of modern awards.
Division4A provides for the FWC to conduct 4 yearly reviews of default fund terms of modern awards.
It also sets out the process for making the Schedule of Approved Employer MySuper products in a 4 yearly review, and amending the schedule after it is made to include other employer MySuper products. If an employer MySuper product is on the schedule, an employer covered by a modern award can make contributions, for the benefit of a default fund employee, to a superannuation fund that offers the product (see subsection149D(1A)).
Division5 provides for the FWC to exercise modern award powers in certain circumstances.
Division6 contains some general provisions relating to modern award powers.
Division7 contains additional provisions relating to modern enterprise awards.
Division8 contains additional provisions relating to State reference public sector modern awards.
The obligation to comply with a modern award is in section45 (in Part2‑1).
In relation to minimum wages in modern awards, the FWC has powers both under this Part and under Part2‑6 (which deals with minimum wages). The following is a summary of the FWC’s powers under the 2Parts:
(a)the initial making of a modern award setting modern award minimum wages can only occur under this Part;
(b)the main power to vary modern award minimum wages is in annual wage reviews under Part2‑6;
(c)modern award minimum wages can also be varied under this Part, but only for work value reasons or in other limited circumstances;
(d)modern award minimum wages can be set (otherwise than in the initial making of a modern award) or revoked either under this Part or in annual wage reviews under Part2‑6.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s132/a.content: the initial making of a modern award setting modern award minimum wages can only occur under this Part; This Part provides for the FWC to make, vary and revoke modern awards. Modern awards may set minimum terms and conditions for national system employees in particular industries or occupations. Modern awards can have terms that are ancillary or supplementary to the National Employment Standards (see Part2‑1). Division2 provides for the modern awards objective. This requires the FWC to ensure that modern awards, together with the National Employment Standards, provide a fair and relevant minimum safety net of terms and conditions, taking into account certain social and economic factors. Division2 also contains special provisions about modern award minimum wages. Division3 deals with the terms of modern awards. Division4A provides for the FWC to conduct 4 yearly reviews of default fund terms of modern awards. It also sets out the process for making the Schedule of Approved Employer MySuper products in a 4 yearly review, and amending the schedule after it is made to include other employer MySuper products. If an employer MySuper product is on the schedule, an employer covered by a modern award can make contributions, for the benefit of a default fund employee, to a superannuation fund that offers the product (see subsection149D(1A)). Division5 provides for the FWC to exercise modern award powers in certain circumstances. Division6 contains some general provisions relating to modern award powers. Division7 contains additional provisions relating to modern enterprise awards. Division8 contains additional provisions relating to State reference public sector modern awards. The obligation to comply with a modern award is in section45 (in Part2‑1). In relation to minimum wages in modern awards, the FWC has powers both under this Part and under Part2‑6 (which deals with minimum wages). The following is a summary of the FWC’s powers under the 2Parts:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s132/b.content: the main power to vary modern award minimum wages is in annual wage reviews under Part2‑6;

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s132/c.content: modern award minimum wages can also be varied under this Part, but only for work value reasons or in other limited circumstances;

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s132/d.content: modern award minimum wages can be set (otherwise than in the initial making of a modern award) or revoked either under this Part or in annual wage reviews under Part2‑6.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s133.title: Meanings ofemployeeandemployer
/au-federal/fwa/2009/s133.content: In this Part,employeemeans a national system employee, andemployermeans a national system employer.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s134.title: The modern awards objective
/au-federal/fwa/2009/s134.content:
What is the modern awards objective?
(1)The FWC must ensure that modern awards, together with the National Employment Standards, provide a fair and relevant minimum safety net of terms and conditions, taking into account:
(a)relative living standards and the needs of the low paid; and
(aa)the need to improve access to secure work across the economy; and
(ab)the need to achieve gender equality in the workplace by ensuring equal remuneration for work of equal or comparable value, eliminating gender‑based undervaluation of work and providing workplace conditions that facilitate women’s full economic participation; and
(b)the need to encourage collective bargaining; and
(c)the need to promote social inclusion through increased workforce participation; and
(d)the need to promote flexible modern work practices and the efficient and productive performance of work; and
(da)the need to provide additional remuneration for:
(i)employees working overtime; or
(ii)employees working unsocial, irregular or unpredictable hours; or
(iii)employees working on weekends or public holidays; or
(iv)employees working shifts; and
(f)the likely impact of any exercise of modern award powers on business, including on productivity, employment costs and the regulatory burden; and
(g)the need to ensure a simple, easy to understand, stable and sustainable modern award system for Australia that avoids unnecessary overlap of modern awards; and
(h)the likely impact of any exercise of modern award powers on employment growth, inflation and the sustainability, performance and competitiveness of the national economy.
This is themodern awards objective.
When does the modern awards objective apply?
(2)The modern awards objective applies to the performance or exercise of the FWC’smodern award powers, which are:
(a)the FWC’s functions or powers under this Part; and
(b)the FWC’s functions or powers under Part2‑6, so far as they relate to modern award minimum wages.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s134/1.content: The FWC must ensure that modern awards, together with the National Employment Standards, provide a fair and relevant minimum safety net of terms and conditions, taking into account: What is the modern awards objective?

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s134/1/a.content: relative living standards and the needs of the low paid; and

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s134/1/aa.content: the need to improve access to secure work across the economy; and

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s134/1/ab.content: the need to achieve gender equality in the workplace by ensuring equal remuneration for work of equal or comparable value, eliminating gender‑based undervaluation of work and providing workplace conditions that facilitate women’s full economic participation; and

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s134/1/b.content: the need to encourage collective bargaining; and

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s134/1/c.content: the need to promote social inclusion through increased workforce participation; and

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s134/1/d.content: the need to promote flexible modern work practices and the efficient and productive performance of work; and

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s134/1/da.content: the need to provide additional remuneration for:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s134/1/ii.content: employees working unsocial, irregular or unpredictable hours; or

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s134/1/iii.content: employees working on weekends or public holidays; or

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s134/1/f.content: the likely impact of any exercise of modern award powers on business, including on productivity, employment costs and the regulatory burden; and

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s134/1/g.content: the need to ensure a simple, easy to understand, stable and sustainable modern award system for Australia that avoids unnecessary overlap of modern awards; and

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s134/1/h.content: the likely impact of any exercise of modern award powers on employment growth, inflation and the sustainability, performance and competitiveness of the national economy. This is themodern awards objective. When does the modern awards objective apply?

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s134/2.content: The modern awards objective applies to the performance or exercise of the FWC’smodern award powers, which are:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s134/2/a.content: the FWC’s functions or powers under this Part; and

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s134/2/b.content: the FWC’s functions or powers under Part2‑6, so far as they relate to modern award minimum wages.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s135.title: Special provisions relating to modern award minimum wages
/au-federal/fwa/2009/s135.content:
(1)Modern award minimum wages cannot be varied under this Part except as follows:
(a)modern award minimum wages can be varied if the FWC is satisfied that the variation is justified by work value reasons (see subsection157(2));
(b)modern award minimum wages can be varied under section160 (which deals with variation to remove ambiguities or correct errors) or section161 (which deals with variation on referral by the Australian Human Rights Commission).
(2)In exercising its powers under this Part to set, vary or revoke modern award minimum wages, the FWC must take into account the rate of the national minimum wage as currently set in a national minimum wage order.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s135/1.content: Modern award minimum wages cannot be varied under this Part except as follows:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s135/1/a.content: modern award minimum wages can be varied if the FWC is satisfied that the variation is justified by work value reasons (see subsection157(2));

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s135/1/b.content: modern award minimum wages can be varied under section160 (which deals with variation to remove ambiguities or correct errors) or section161 (which deals with variation on referral by the Australian Human Rights Commission).

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s135/2.content: In exercising its powers under this Part to set, vary or revoke modern award minimum wages, the FWC must take into account the rate of the national minimum wage as currently set in a national minimum wage order.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s135A.title: Special provisions relating to penalty rates and overtime rates

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s135A/1.content: In exercising its powers under this Part to make, vary or revoke modern awards, the FWC must ensure that:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s135A/1/a.content: the rate of a penalty rate or an overtime rate that employees are entitled to receive is not reduced; and

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s135A/1/b.content: modern awards do not include terms that substitute employees’ entitlements to receive penalty rates or overtime rates where those terms would have the effect of reducing the additional remuneration referred to in paragraph134(1)(da) that any employee would otherwise receive.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s135A/2.content: Subsection(1) does not limit the operation of section144 (flexibility terms) or section160 (which deals with variation to remove ambiguities or correct errors).

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s135A/3.content: Nothing in subsection(1) requires the FWC to exercise its powers under this Part to make, vary or revoke modern awards.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s136.title: What can be included in modern awards
/au-federal/fwa/2009/s136.content:
Terms that may or must be included
(1)A modern award must only include terms that are permitted or required by:
(a)Subdivision B (which deals with terms that may be included in modern awards); or
(b)Subdivision C (which deals with terms that must be included in modern awards); or
(c)section55 (which deals with interaction between the National Employment Standards and a modern award or enterprise agreement); or
(d)Part2‑2 (which deals with the National Employment Standards).
Terms that must not be included
(2)A modern award must not include terms that contravene:
(a)Subdivision D (which deals with terms that must not be included in modern awards); or
(b)section55 (which deals with the interaction between the National Employment Standards and a modern award or enterprise agreement).

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s136/1.content: A modern award must only include terms that are permitted or required by: Terms that may or must be included

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s136/1/a.content: Subdivision B (which deals with terms that may be included in modern awards); or

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s136/1/b.content: Subdivision C (which deals with terms that must be included in modern awards); or

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s136/1/c.content: section55 (which deals with interaction between the National Employment Standards and a modern award or enterprise agreement); or

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s136/1/d.content: Part2‑2 (which deals with the National Employment Standards). Terms that must not be included

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s136/2.content: A modern award must not include terms that contravene:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s136/2/a.content: Subdivision D (which deals with terms that must not be included in modern awards); or

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s136/2/b.content: section55 (which deals with the interaction between the National Employment Standards and a modern award or enterprise agreement).

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s137.title: Terms that contravene section136 have no effect
/au-federal/fwa/2009/s137.content: A term of a modern award has no effect to the extent that it contravenes section136.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s138.title: Achieving the modern awards objective
/au-federal/fwa/2009/s138.content:
A modern award may include terms that it is permitted to include, and must include terms that it is required to include, only to the extent necessary to achieve the modern awards objective and (to the extent applicable) the minimum wages objective.
Subdivision B—Terms that may be included in modern awards

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s139.title: Terms that may be included in modern awards—general

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s139/1.content: A modern award may include terms about any of the following matters:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s139/1/a.content: minimum wages (including wage rates for junior employees, employees with a disability and employees to whom training arrangements apply), and:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s139/1/ii.content: responsibilities or skills that are not taken into account in rates of pay;

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s139/1/b.content: type of employment, such as full‑time employment, casual employment, regular part‑time employment and shift work, and the facilitation of flexible working arrangements, particularly for employees with family responsibilities;

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s139/1/c.content: arrangements for when work is performed, including hours of work, rostering, notice periods, rest breaks and variations to working hours;

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s139/1/e.content: penalty rates, including for any of the following:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s139/1/iii.content: disabilities associated with the performance of particular tasks or work in particular conditions or locations;

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s139/1/g.content: allowances, including for any of the following:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s139/1/h.content: leave, leave loadings and arrangements for taking leave;

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s139/1/j.content: procedures for consultation, representation and dispute settlement.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s139/2.content: Any allowance included in a modern award must be separately and clearly identified in the award.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s140.title: Outworker terms

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s140/1.content: A modern award may include either or both of the following:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s140/1/a.content: terms relating to the conditions under which an employer may employ employees who are outworkers;

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s140/1/b.content: terms relating to the conditions under which an outworker entity may arrange for work to be performed for the entity (either directly or indirectly), if the work is of a kind that is often performed by outworkers.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s140/2.content: Without limiting subsection(1), terms referred to in that subsection may include terms relating to the pay or conditions of outworkers.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s140/3.content: The following terms of a modern award areoutworker terms:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s140/3/b.content: terms that are incidental to terms referred to in subsection(1), included in the modern award under subsection142(1);

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s140/3/c.content: machinery terms in relation to terms referred to in subsection(1), included in the modern award under subsection142(2).

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s141.title: Industry‑specific redundancy schemes
/au-federal/fwa/2009/s141.content:
When can a modern award include an industry‑specific redundancy scheme?
(1)A modern award may include an industry‑specific redundancy scheme if the scheme was included in the award:
(a)in theaward modernisation process; or
(b)in accordance with subsection(2).
Coverage of industry‑specific redundancy schemes must not be extended
(2)If:
(a)a modern award includes an industry‑specific redundancy scheme; and
(b)the FWC is making or varying another modern award under Division5 so that it (rather than the modern award referred to in paragraph(a)) will cover some or all of the classes of employees who are covered by the scheme;
the FWC may include the scheme in that other modern award. However, the FWC must not extend the coverage of the scheme to classes of employees that it did not previously cover.
Varying industry‑specific redundancy schemes
(3)The FWC may only vary an industry‑specific redundancy scheme in a modern award underDivision5:
(a)by varying the amount of any redundancy payment in the scheme; or
(b)in accordance with a provision of Subdivision B of Division5 (which deals with varying modern awards in some limited situations).
(4)In varying an industry‑specific redundancy scheme as referred to in subsection(3), the FWC:
(a)must not extend the coverage of the scheme to classes of employees that it did not previously cover; and
(b)must retain the industry‑specific character of the scheme.
Omitting industry‑specific redundancy schemes
(5)The FWC may vary a modern award under Division5 by omitting an industry‑specific redundancy scheme from the award.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s141/1.content: A modern award may include an industry‑specific redundancy scheme if the scheme was included in the award: When can a modern award include an industry‑specific redundancy scheme?

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s141/1/b.content: in accordance with subsection(2). Coverage of industry‑specific redundancy schemes must not be extended

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s141/2/a.content: a modern award includes an industry‑specific redundancy scheme; and

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s141/2/b.content: the FWC is making or varying another modern award under Division5 so that it (rather than the modern award referred to in paragraph(a)) will cover some or all of the classes of employees who are covered by the scheme; the FWC may include the scheme in that other modern award. However, the FWC must not extend the coverage of the scheme to classes of employees that it did not previously cover. Varying industry‑specific redundancy schemes

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s141/3.content: The FWC may only vary an industry‑specific redundancy scheme in a modern award underDivision5:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s141/3/a.content: by varying the amount of any redundancy payment in the scheme; or

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s141/3/b.content: in accordance with a provision of Subdivision B of Division5 (which deals with varying modern awards in some limited situations).

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s141/4.content: In varying an industry‑specific redundancy scheme as referred to in subsection(3), the FWC:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s141/4/a.content: must not extend the coverage of the scheme to classes of employees that it did not previously cover; and

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s141/4/b.content: must retain the industry‑specific character of the scheme. Omitting industry‑specific redundancy schemes

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s141/5.content: The FWC may vary a modern award under Division5 by omitting an industry‑specific redundancy scheme from the award.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s141A.title: Terms permitting fixed term contracts
/au-federal/fwa/2009/s141A.content:
(1)A modern award may include terms that permit an employee to be employed under a contract of employment that includes a term that provides the contract will terminate at the end of an identifiable period (whether or not the contract also includes other terms that provide for circumstances in which it may be terminated before the end of that period).
(2)Without limiting subsection(1), a modern award may include terms that permit any of the circumstances mentioned in subsections333E(2) to (4) (about certain fixed term contracts) to occur.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s141A/1.content: A modern award may include terms that permit an employee to be employed under a contract of employment that includes a term that provides the contract will terminate at the end of an identifiable period (whether or not the contract also includes other terms that provide for circumstances in which it may be terminated before the end of that period).

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s141A/2.content: Without limiting subsection(1), a modern award may include terms that permit any of the circumstances mentioned in subsections333E(2) to (4) (about certain fixed term contracts) to occur.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s142.title: Incidental and machinery terms
/au-federal/fwa/2009/s142.content:
Incidental terms
(1)A modern award may include terms that are:
(a)incidental to a term that is permitted or required to be in the modern award; and
(b)essential for the purpose of making a particular term operate in a practical way.
Machinery terms
(2)A modern award may include machinery terms, including formal matters (such as a title, date or table of contents).
Subdivision C—Terms that must be included in modern awards

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s142/1.content: A modern award may include terms that are: Incidental terms

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s142/1/a.content: incidental to a term that is permitted or required to be in the modern award; and

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s142/1/b.content: essential for the purpose of making a particular term operate in a practical way. Machinery terms

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s142/2.content: A modern award may include machinery terms, including formal matters (such as a title, date or table of contents). Subdivision C—Terms that must be included in modern awards

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s143.title: Coverage terms of modern awards other than modern enterprise awards and State reference public sector modern awards
/au-federal/fwa/2009/s143.content:
Coverage terms must be included
(1)A modern award must include terms (coverage terms) setting out the employers, employees, organisations and outworker entities that are covered by the award, in accordance with this section.
Employers and employees
(2)A modern award must be expressed to cover:
(a)specified employers; and
(b)specified employees of employers covered by the modern award.
Organisations
(3)A modern award may be expressed to cover one or more specified organisations, in relation to all or specified employees or employers that are covered by the award.
Outworker entities
(4)A modern award may be expressed to cover, but only in relation to outworker terms included in the award, specified outworker entities.
How coverage is expressed
(5)For the purposes of subsections(2) to (4):
(a)employers may be specified by name or by inclusion in a specified class or specified classes; and
(b)employees must be specified by inclusion in a specified class or specified classes; and
(c)organisations must be specified by name; and
(d)outworker entities may be specified by name or by inclusion in a specified class or specified classes.
(6)Without limiting the way in which a class may be described for the purposes of subsection(5), the class may be described by reference to a particular industry or part of an industry, or particular kinds of work.
Employees not traditionally covered by awards etc.
(7)A modern award must not be expressed to cover classes of employees:
(a)who, because of the nature or seniority of their role, have traditionally not been covered by awards (whether made under laws of the Commonwealth or the States); or
(b)who perform work that is not of a similar nature to work that has traditionally been regulated by such awards.
Modern enterprise awards
(8)A modern award (other than a modern enterprise award) must be expressed not to cover employees who are covered by a modern enterprise award, or an enterprise instrument (within the meaning of the Transitional Act), or employers in relation to those employees.
(9)This section does not apply to modern enterprise awards.
State reference public sector modern awards
(10)A modern award (other than a State reference public sector modern award) must be expressed not to cover employees who are covered by a State reference public sector modern award, or a State reference public sector transitional award (within the meaning of the Transitional Act), or employers in relation to those employees.
(11)This section does not apply to State reference public sector modern awards.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s143/1.content: A modern award must include terms (coverage terms) setting out the employers, employees, organisations and outworker entities that are covered by the award, in accordance with this section. Coverage terms must be included Employers and employees

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s143/2.content: A modern award must be expressed to cover:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s143/2/b.content: specified employees of employers covered by the modern award. Organisations

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s143/3.content: A modern award may be expressed to cover one or more specified organisations, in relation to all or specified employees or employers that are covered by the award. Outworker entities

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s143/4.content: A modern award may be expressed to cover, but only in relation to outworker terms included in the award, specified outworker entities. How coverage is expressed

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s143/5.content: For the purposes of subsections(2) to (4):

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s143/5/a.content: employers may be specified by name or by inclusion in a specified class or specified classes; and

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s143/5/b.content: employees must be specified by inclusion in a specified class or specified classes; and

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s143/5/c.content: organisations must be specified by name; and

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s143/5/d.content: outworker entities may be specified by name or by inclusion in a specified class or specified classes.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s143/6.content: Without limiting the way in which a class may be described for the purposes of subsection(5), the class may be described by reference to a particular industry or part of an industry, or particular kinds of work. Employees not traditionally covered by awards etc.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s143/7.content: A modern award must not be expressed to cover classes of employees:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s143/7/a.content: who, because of the nature or seniority of their role, have traditionally not been covered by awards (whether made under laws of the Commonwealth or the States); or

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s143/7/b.content: who perform work that is not of a similar nature to work that has traditionally been regulated by such awards. Modern enterprise awards

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s143/8.content: A modern award (other than a modern enterprise award) must be expressed not to cover employees who are covered by a modern enterprise award, or an enterprise instrument (within the meaning of the Transitional Act), or employers in relation to those employees.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s143/9.content: This section does not apply to modern enterprise awards. State reference public sector modern awards

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s143/10.content: A modern award (other than a State reference public sector modern award) must be expressed not to cover employees who are covered by a State reference public sector modern award, or a State reference public sector transitional award (within the meaning of the Transitional Act), or employers in relation to those employees.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s143/11.content: This section does not apply to State reference public sector modern awards.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s143A.title: Coverage terms of modern enterprise awards
/au-federal/fwa/2009/s143A.content:
Coverage terms must be included
(1)A modern enterprise award must include terms (coverage terms) setting out, in accordance with this section:
(a)the enterprise or enterprises to which the modern enterprise award relates; and
(b)the employers, employees and organisations that are covered by the modern enterprise award.
Enterprises
(2)A modern enterprise award must be expressed to relate:
(a)to a single enterprise (or a part of a single enterprise) only; or
(b)to one or more enterprises, but only if the employers all carry on similar business activities under the same franchise and are:
(i)franchisees of the same franchisor; or
(ii)related bodies corporate of the same franchisor; or
(iii)any combination of the above.
Employers and employees
(3)A modern enterprise award must be expressed to cover:
(a)a specified employer that carries on, or specified employers that carry on, the enterprise or enterprises referred to in subsection(2); and
