(b)specified employees of employers covered by the modern enterprise award.
Organisations
(4)A modern enterprise award may be expressed to cover one or more specified organisations, in relation to:
(a)all or specified employees covered by the award; or
(b)the employer, or all or specified employers, covered by the award.
Outworker entities
(5)A modern enterprise award must not be expressed to cover outworker entities.
How coverage etc. is expressed
(6)For the purposes of subsection(2), an enterprise must be specified:
(a)if paragraph(2)(a) applies to the enterprise—by name; or
(b)if paragraph(2)(b) applies to the enterprise—by name, or by the name of the franchise.
(7)For the purposes of subsections(3) and (4):
(a)an employer or employers may be specified by name or by inclusion in a specified class or specified classes; and
(b)employees must be specified by inclusion in a specified class or specified classes; and
(c)organisations must be specified by name.
Employees not traditionally covered by awards etc.
(8)A modern enterprise award must not be expressed to cover classes of employees:
(a)who, because of the nature or seniority of their role, have traditionally not been covered by awards (whether made under laws of the Commonwealth or the States); or
(b)who perform work that is not of a similar nature to work that has traditionally been regulated by such awards.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s143A/1.content: A modern enterprise award must include terms (coverage terms) setting out, in accordance with this section: Coverage terms must be included

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s143A/1/a.content: the enterprise or enterprises to which the modern enterprise award relates; and

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s143A/1/b.content: the employers, employees and organisations that are covered by the modern enterprise award. Enterprises

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s143A/2.content: A modern enterprise award must be expressed to relate:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s143A/2/a.content: to a single enterprise (or a part of a single enterprise) only; or

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s143A/2/b.content: to one or more enterprises, but only if the employers all carry on similar business activities under the same franchise and are:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s143A/2/i.content: franchisees of the same franchisor; or

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s143A/2/ii.content: related bodies corporate of the same franchisor; or

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s143A/2/iii.content: any combination of the above. Employers and employees

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s143A/3.content: A modern enterprise award must be expressed to cover:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s143A/3/a.content: a specified employer that carries on, or specified employers that carry on, the enterprise or enterprises referred to in subsection(2); and

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s143A/3/b.content: specified employees of employers covered by the modern enterprise award. Organisations

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s143A/4.content: A modern enterprise award may be expressed to cover one or more specified organisations, in relation to:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s143A/4/a.content: all or specified employees covered by the award; or

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s143A/4/b.content: the employer, or all or specified employers, covered by the award. Outworker entities

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s143A/5.content: A modern enterprise award must not be expressed to cover outworker entities. How coverage etc. is expressed

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s143A/6.content: For the purposes of subsection(2), an enterprise must be specified:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s143A/6/a.content: if paragraph(2)(a) applies to the enterprise—by name; or

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s143A/6/b.content: if paragraph(2)(b) applies to the enterprise—by name, or by the name of the franchise.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s143A/7.content: For the purposes of subsections(3) and (4):

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s143A/7/a.content: an employer or employers may be specified by name or by inclusion in a specified class or specified classes; and

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s143A/7/b.content: employees must be specified by inclusion in a specified class or specified classes; and

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s143A/7/c.content: organisations must be specified by name. Employees not traditionally covered by awards etc.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s143A/8.content: A modern enterprise award must not be expressed to cover classes of employees:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s143A/8/a.content: who, because of the nature or seniority of their role, have traditionally not been covered by awards (whether made under laws of the Commonwealth or the States); or

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s143A/8/b.content: who perform work that is not of a similar nature to work that has traditionally been regulated by such awards.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s143B.title: Coverage terms of State reference public sector modern awards
/au-federal/fwa/2009/s143B.content:
Coverage terms must be included
(1)A State reference public sector modern award must include terms (coverage terms) setting out, in accordance with this section, the employers, employees and organisations that are covered by the modern award.
Employers and employees
(2)The coverage terms must be such that:
(a)the only employers that are expressed to be covered by the modern award are one or more specified State reference public sector employers; and
(b)the only employees who are expressed to be covered by the modern award are specified State reference public sector employees of those employers.
Organisations
(3)A State reference public sector modern award may be expressed to cover one or more specified organisations, in relation to:
(a)all or specified employees covered by the modern award; or
(b)the employer, or all or specified employers, covered by the modern award.
Outworker entities
(4)A State reference public sector modern award must not be expressed to cover outworker entities.
How coverage etc. is expressed
(5)For the purposes of this section:
(a)an employer or employers may be specified by name or by inclusion in a specified class or specified classes; and
(b)employees must be specified by inclusion in a specified class or specified classes; and
(c)organisations must be specified by name.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s143B/1.content: A State reference public sector modern award must include terms (coverage terms) setting out, in accordance with this section, the employers, employees and organisations that are covered by the modern award. Coverage terms must be included Employers and employees

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s143B/2.content: The coverage terms must be such that:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s143B/2/a.content: the only employers that are expressed to be covered by the modern award are one or more specified State reference public sector employers; and

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s143B/2/b.content: the only employees who are expressed to be covered by the modern award are specified State reference public sector employees of those employers. Organisations

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s143B/3.content: A State reference public sector modern award may be expressed to cover one or more specified organisations, in relation to:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s143B/3/a.content: all or specified employees covered by the modern award; or

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s143B/3/b.content: the employer, or all or specified employers, covered by the modern award. Outworker entities

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s143B/4.content: A State reference public sector modern award must not be expressed to cover outworker entities. How coverage etc. is expressed

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s143B/5.content: For the purposes of this section:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s143B/5/a.content: an employer or employers may be specified by name or by inclusion in a specified class or specified classes; and

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s143B/5/b.content: employees must be specified by inclusion in a specified class or specified classes; and

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s143B/5/c.content: organisations must be specified by name.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s144.title: Flexibility terms
/au-federal/fwa/2009/s144.content:
Flexibility terms must be included
(1)A modern award must include a term (aflexibility term) enabling an employee and his or her employer to agree on an arrangement (anindividualflexibility arrangement) varying the effect of the award in relation to the employee and the employer, in order to meet the genuine needs of the employee and employer.
Effect of individual flexibility arrangements
(2)If an employee and employer agree to an individual flexibility arrangement under a flexibility term in a modern award:
(a)the modern award has effect in relation to the employee and the employer as if it were varied by the flexibility arrangement; and
(b)the arrangement is taken, for the purposes of this Act, to be a term of the modern award.
(3)To avoid doubt, the individual flexibility arrangement does not change the effect the modern award has in relation to the employer and any other employee.
Requirements for flexibility terms
(4)The flexibility term must:
(a)identify the terms of the modern award the effect of which may be varied by an individual flexibility arrangement; and
(b)require that the employee and the employer genuinely agree to any individual flexibility arrangement; and
(c)require the employer to ensure that any individual flexibility arrangement must result in the employee being better off overall than the employee would have been if no individual flexibility arrangement were agreed to; and
(d)set out how any flexibility arrangement may be terminated by the employee or the employer; and
(e)require the employer to ensure that any individual flexibility arrangement must be in writing and signed:
(i)in all cases—by the employee and the employer; and
(ii)if the employee is under 18—by a parent or guardian of the employee; and
(f)require the employer to ensure that a copy of any individual flexibility arrangement must be given to the employee.
(5)Except as required by subparagraph(4)(e)(ii), the flexibility term must not require that any individual flexibility arrangement agreed to by an employer and employee under the term must be approved, or consented to, by another person.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s144/1.content: A modern award must include a term (aflexibility term) enabling an employee and his or her employer to agree on an arrangement (anindividualflexibility arrangement) varying the effect of the award in relation to the employee and the employer, in order to meet the genuine needs of the employee and employer. Flexibility terms must be included Effect of individual flexibility arrangements

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s144/2.content: If an employee and employer agree to an individual flexibility arrangement under a flexibility term in a modern award:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s144/2/a.content: the modern award has effect in relation to the employee and the employer as if it were varied by the flexibility arrangement; and

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s144/2/b.content: the arrangement is taken, for the purposes of this Act, to be a term of the modern award.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s144/3.content: To avoid doubt, the individual flexibility arrangement does not change the effect the modern award has in relation to the employer and any other employee. Requirements for flexibility terms

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s144/4/a.content: identify the terms of the modern award the effect of which may be varied by an individual flexibility arrangement; and

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s144/4/b.content: require that the employee and the employer genuinely agree to any individual flexibility arrangement; and

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s144/4/c.content: require the employer to ensure that any individual flexibility arrangement must result in the employee being better off overall than the employee would have been if no individual flexibility arrangement were agreed to; and

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s144/4/d.content: set out how any flexibility arrangement may be terminated by the employee or the employer; and

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s144/4/e.content: require the employer to ensure that any individual flexibility arrangement must be in writing and signed:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s144/4/i.content: in all cases—by the employee and the employer; and

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s144/4/ii.content: if the employee is under 18—by a parent or guardian of the employee; and

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s144/4/f.content: require the employer to ensure that a copy of any individual flexibility arrangement must be given to the employee.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s144/5.content: Except as required by subparagraph(4)(e)(ii), the flexibility term must not require that any individual flexibility arrangement agreed to by an employer and employee under the term must be approved, or consented to, by another person.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s145.title: Effect of individual flexibility arrangement that does not meet requirements of flexibility term
/au-federal/fwa/2009/s145.content:
Application of this section
(1)This section applies if:
(a)an employee and employer agree to an arrangement that purports to be an individual flexibility arrangement under a flexibility term in a modern award; and
(b)the arrangement does not meet a requirement set out in section144.
Arrangement has effect as if it were an individual flexibility arrangement
(2)The arrangement has effect as if it were an individual flexibility arrangement.
Employer contravenes flexibility term in specified circumstances
(3)If subsection144(4) requires the employer to ensure that the arrangement meets the requirement, the employer contravenes the flexibility term of the award.
Flexibility arrangement may be terminated by agreement or notice
(4)The flexibility term is taken to provide (in addition to any other means of termination of the arrangement that the term provides) that the arrangement can be terminated:
(a)by either the employee, or the employer, giving written notice of not more than 28 days; or
(b)by the employee and the employer at any time if they agree, in writing, to the termination.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s145/1.content: This section applies if: Application of this section

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s145/1/a.content: an employee and employer agree to an arrangement that purports to be an individual flexibility arrangement under a flexibility term in a modern award; and

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s145/1/b.content: the arrangement does not meet a requirement set out in section144. Arrangement has effect as if it were an individual flexibility arrangement

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s145/2.content: The arrangement has effect as if it were an individual flexibility arrangement. Employer contravenes flexibility term in specified circumstances

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s145/3.content: If subsection144(4) requires the employer to ensure that the arrangement meets the requirement, the employer contravenes the flexibility term of the award. Flexibility arrangement may be terminated by agreement or notice

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s145/4.content: The flexibility term is taken to provide (in addition to any other means of termination of the arrangement that the term provides) that the arrangement can be terminated:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s145/4/a.content: by either the employee, or the employer, giving written notice of not more than 28 days; or

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s145/4/b.content: by the employee and the employer at any time if they agree, in writing, to the termination.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s145A.title: Consultation about changes to rosters or hours of work
/au-federal/fwa/2009/s145A.content:
(1)Without limiting paragraph139(1)(j), a modern award must include a term that:
(a)requires the employer to consult employees about a change to their regular roster or ordinary hours of work; and
(b)allows for the representation of those employees for the purposes of that consultation.
(2)The term must require the employer:
(a)to provide information to the employees about the change; and
(b)to invite the employees to give their views about the impact of the change (including any impact in relation to their family or caring responsibilities); and
(c)to consider any views about the impact of the change that are given by the employees.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s145A/1.content: Without limiting paragraph139(1)(j), a modern award must include a term that:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s145A/1/a.content: requires the employer to consult employees about a change to their regular roster or ordinary hours of work; and

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s145A/1/b.content: allows for the representation of those employees for the purposes of that consultation.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s145A/2.content: The term must require the employer:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s145A/2/a.content: to provide information to the employees about the change; and

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s145A/2/b.content: to invite the employees to give their views about the impact of the change (including any impact in relation to their family or caring responsibilities); and

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s145A/2/c.content: to consider any views about the impact of the change that are given by the employees.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s146.title: Terms about settling disputes
/au-federal/fwa/2009/s146.content:
Without limiting paragraph139(1)(j), a modern award must include a term that provides a procedure for settling disputes:
(a)about any matters arising under the award; and
(b)in relation to the National Employment Standards.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s146/a.content: about any matters arising under the award; and Without limiting paragraph139(1)(j), a modern award must include a term that provides a procedure for settling disputes:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s146/b.content: in relation to the National Employment Standards.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s147.title: Ordinary hours of work
/au-federal/fwa/2009/s147.content: A modern award must include terms specifying, or providing for the determination of, the ordinary hours of work for each classification of employee covered by the award and each type of employment permitted by the award.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s148.title: Base and full rates of pay for pieceworkers
/au-federal/fwa/2009/s148.content: If a modern award defines or describes employees covered by the award as pieceworkers, the award must include terms specifying, or providing for the determination of, base and full rates of pay for those employees for the purposes of the National Employment Standards.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s149.title: Automatic variation of allowances
/au-federal/fwa/2009/s149.content: If a modern award includes allowances that the FWC considers are of a kind that should be varied when wage rates inthe award are varied, the award must include terms providing for the automatic variation of those allowances when wage rates in the award are varied.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s149B.title: Term requiring avoidance of liability to pay superannuation guarantee charge
/au-federal/fwa/2009/s149B.content:
(1)A modern award must include a term that requires an employer covered by the award to make contributions to a superannuation fund for the benefit of an employee covered by the award so as to avoid liability to pay superannuation guarantee charge under theSuperannuation Guarantee Charge Act 1992in relation to the employee.
Reduction of employer’s liability to the extent of superannuation charge payments
(2)The obligation of an employer to make contributions for the benefit of an employee under a term mentioned in subsection(1) does not apply to the extent that:
(a)the employer has made a charge payment (within the meaning of section63A of theSuperannuation Guarantee (Administration) Act 1992) in respect of the employee under Part8 of that Act; and
(b)the employee is a benefiting employee (within the meaning of that Part); and
(c)the Commissioner of Taxation is required to pay, or otherwise deal with, a shortfall component (within the meaning of that Part) for the benefit of the employee under that Part.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s149B/1.content: A modern award must include a term that requires an employer covered by the award to make contributions to a superannuation fund for the benefit of an employee covered by the award so as to avoid liability to pay superannuation guarantee charge under theSuperannuation Guarantee Charge Act 1992in relation to the employee. Reduction of employer’s liability to the extent of superannuation charge payments

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s149B/2.content: The obligation of an employer to make contributions for the benefit of an employee under a term mentioned in subsection(1) does not apply to the extent that:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s149B/2/a.content: the employer has made a charge payment (within the meaning of section63A of theSuperannuation Guarantee (Administration) Act 1992) in respect of the employee under Part8 of that Act; and

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s149B/2/b.content: the employee is a benefiting employee (within the meaning of that Part); and

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s149B/2/c.content: the Commissioner of Taxation is required to pay, or otherwise deal with, a shortfall component (within the meaning of that Part) for the benefit of the employee under that Part.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s149C.title: Default fund terms
/au-federal/fwa/2009/s149C.content:
(1)A modern award must include a default fund term that complies with section149D.
(2)Adefault fund termis a term of a modern award that requires, permits or prohibits an employer covered by the award to make contributions to a superannuation fund for the benefit of an employee (adefault fund employee) who:
(a)is covered by the award; and
(b)has no chosen fund (within the meaning of theSuperannuation Guarantee (Administration) Act 1992).

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s149C/1.content: A modern award must include a default fund term that complies with section149D.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s149C/2.content: Adefault fund termis a term of a modern award that requires, permits or prohibits an employer covered by the award to make contributions to a superannuation fund for the benefit of an employee (adefault fund employee) who:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s149C/2/a.content: is covered by the award; and

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s149C/2/b.content: has no chosen fund (within the meaning of theSuperannuation Guarantee (Administration) Act 1992).

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s149D.title: Default fund term must provide for contributions to be made to certain funds
/au-federal/fwa/2009/s149D.content:
Specified superannuation fund offering standard MySuper product
(1)A default fund term of a modern award must require an employer covered by the award to make contributions, for the benefit of a default fund employee, to a superannuation fund that:
(a)offers a standard MySuper product; and
(b)is specified in the default fund term of the award in relation to that product;
(c)the employer will be liable to pay superannuation guarantee charge under theSuperannuation Guarantee Charge Act 1992in relation to the employee if the employer does not make contributions to a superannuation fund for the benefit of the employee; and
(d)the employer is not making contributions to a superannuation fund referred to in subsection(1A), (2), (3), (4) or (5) for the benefit of the employee.
Superannuation funds offering employer MySuper products on the schedule
(1A)A default fund term of a modern award must permit an employer covered by the award to make contributions, for the benefit of a default fund employee, to a superannuation fund that offers an employer MySuper product that:
(a)relates to the employer; and
(b)is on the Schedule of Approved Employer MySuper Products.
Defined Benefits Scheme
(2)A default fund term of a modern award must permit an employer covered by the award to make contributions, for the benefit of a default fund employee, to a superannuation fund in relation to which a default fund employee is a defined benefit member.
Exempt public sector superannuation scheme
(3)A default fund term of a modern award must permit an employer covered by the award to make contributions, for the benefit of a default fund employee, to a superannuation fund that is an exempt public sector superannuation scheme.
State public sector superannuation scheme
(4)A default fund term of a modern award must permit an employer covered by the award to make contributions, for the benefit of a default fund employee, to a superannuation fund that:
(a)is a public sector superannuation scheme (within the meaning of theSuperannuation Industry (Supervision) Act 1993); and
(b)a law of a State requires the employer to make contributions to for the benefit of the employee.
Transitionally authorised superannuation fund
(5)A default fund term of a modern award must permit an employer covered by the award to make contributions, for the benefit of a default fund employee, to a superannuation fund in relation to which a transitional authorisation is in operation under section156K.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s149D/1.content: A default fund term of a modern award must require an employer covered by the award to make contributions, for the benefit of a default fund employee, to a superannuation fund that: Specified superannuation fund offering standard MySuper product

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s149D/1/b.content: is on the Schedule of Approved Employer MySuper Products. Defined Benefits Scheme

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s149D/1/c.content: the employer will be liable to pay superannuation guarantee charge under theSuperannuation Guarantee Charge Act 1992in relation to the employee if the employer does not make contributions to a superannuation fund for the benefit of the employee; and

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s149D/1/d.content: the employer is not making contributions to a superannuation fund referred to in subsection(1A), (2), (3), (4) or (5) for the benefit of the employee. Superannuation funds offering employer MySuper products on the schedule (1A)A default fund term of a modern award must permit an employer covered by the award to make contributions, for the benefit of a default fund employee, to a superannuation fund that offers an employer MySuper product that:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s149D/2.content: A default fund term of a modern award must permit an employer covered by the award to make contributions, for the benefit of a default fund employee, to a superannuation fund in relation to which a default fund employee is a defined benefit member. Exempt public sector superannuation scheme

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s149D/3.content: A default fund term of a modern award must permit an employer covered by the award to make contributions, for the benefit of a default fund employee, to a superannuation fund that is an exempt public sector superannuation scheme. State public sector superannuation scheme

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s149D/4.content: A default fund term of a modern award must permit an employer covered by the award to make contributions, for the benefit of a default fund employee, to a superannuation fund that:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s149D/4/a.content: is a public sector superannuation scheme (within the meaning of theSuperannuation Industry (Supervision) Act 1993); and

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s149D/4/b.content: a law of a State requires the employer to make contributions to for the benefit of the employee. Transitionally authorised superannuation fund

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s149D/5.content: A default fund term of a modern award must permit an employer covered by the award to make contributions, for the benefit of a default fund employee, to a superannuation fund in relation to which a transitional authorisation is in operation under section156K.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s149E.title: Workplace delegates’ rights
/au-federal/fwa/2009/s149E.content: A modern award must include a delegates’ rights term for workplace delegates covered by the award.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s149F.title: Right to disconnect
/au-federal/fwa/2009/s149F.content:
A modern award must include a right to disconnect term.
Subdivision D—Terms that must not be included in modern awards

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s150.title: Objectionable terms
/au-federal/fwa/2009/s150.content: A modern award must not include an objectionable term.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s151.title: Terms about payments and deductions for benefit of employer etc.
/au-federal/fwa/2009/s151.content:
A modern award must not include a term that has no effect because of:
(a)subsection326(1) (which deals with unreasonable deductions for the benefit of an employer); or
(b)subsection326(3) (which deals with unreasonable requirements to spend or pay an amount); or
(c)subsection326(4) (which deals with deductions or payments in relation to employees under 18).

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s151/a.content: subsection326(1) (which deals with unreasonable deductions for the benefit of an employer); or A modern award must not include a term that has no effect because of:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s151/b.content: subsection326(3) (which deals with unreasonable requirements to spend or pay an amount); or

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s151/c.content: subsection326(4) (which deals with deductions or payments in relation to employees under 18).

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s152.title: Terms about right of entry
/au-federal/fwa/2009/s152.content:
A modern award must not include terms that require or authorise an official of an organisation to enter premises:
(a)to hold discussions with, or interview, an employee; or
(b)to inspect any work, process or object.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s152/a.content: to hold discussions with, or interview, an employee; or A modern award must not include terms that require or authorise an official of an organisation to enter premises:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s152/b.content: to inspect any work, process or object.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s153.title: Terms that are discriminatory
/au-federal/fwa/2009/s153.content:
Discriminatory terms must not be included
(1)A modern award must not include terms that discriminate against an employee because of, or for reasons including, the employee’s race, colour, sex, sexual orientation, breastfeeding, gender identity, intersex status, age, physical or mental disability, marital status, family or carer’s responsibilities, subjection to family and domestic violence, pregnancy, religion, political opinion, national extraction or social origin.
Certain terms are not discriminatory
(2)A term of a modern award does not discriminate against an employee:
(a)if the reason for the discrimination is the inherent requirements of the particular position held by the employee; or
(b)merely because it discriminates, in relation to employment of the employee as a member of the staff of an institution that is conducted in accordance with the doctrines, tenets, beliefs or teachings of a particular religion or creed:
(i)in good faith; and
(ii)to avoid injury to the religious susceptibilities of adherents of that religion or creed.
(3)A term of a modern award does not discriminate against an employee merely because it provides for minimum wages for:
(a)all junior employees, or a class of junior employees; or
(b)all employees with a disability, or a class of employees with a disability; or
(c)all employees to whom training arrangements apply, or a class of employees to whom training arrangements apply.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s153/1.content: A modern award must not include terms that discriminate against an employee because of, or for reasons including, the employee’s race, colour, sex, sexual orientation, breastfeeding, gender identity, intersex status, age, physical or mental disability, marital status, family or carer’s responsibilities, subjection to family and domestic violence, pregnancy, religion, political opinion, national extraction or social origin. Discriminatory terms must not be included Certain terms are not discriminatory

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s153/2.content: A term of a modern award does not discriminate against an employee:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s153/2/a.content: if the reason for the discrimination is the inherent requirements of the particular position held by the employee; or

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s153/2/b.content: merely because it discriminates, in relation to employment of the employee as a member of the staff of an institution that is conducted in accordance with the doctrines, tenets, beliefs or teachings of a particular religion or creed:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s153/2/ii.content: to avoid injury to the religious susceptibilities of adherents of that religion or creed.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s153/3.content: A term of a modern award does not discriminate against an employee merely because it provides for minimum wages for:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s153/3/a.content: all junior employees, or a class of junior employees; or

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s153/3/b.content: all employees with a disability, or a class of employees with a disability; or

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s153/3/c.content: all employees to whom training arrangements apply, or a class of employees to whom training arrangements apply.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s154.title: Terms that contain State‑based differences
/au-federal/fwa/2009/s154.content:
General rule—State‑based difference terms must not be included
(1)A modern award must not include terms and conditions of employment (State‑based difference terms)that:
(a)are determined by reference to State or Territory boundaries; or
(b)are expressed to operate in one or more, but not every, State and Territory.
When State‑based difference terms may be included
(2)However, a modern award may include State‑based difference terms if the terms were included in the award:
(a)in the award modernisation process; or
(b)in accordance with subsection(3);
but only for up to 5 years starting on the day on which the first modern award that included those terms came into operation.
(3)If:
(a)a modern award includes State‑based difference terms as permitted under subsection(2); and
(b)the FWC is making or varying another modern award so that it (rather than the modern award referred to in paragraph(a)) will cover some or all of the classes of employees who are covered by those terms;
the FWC may include those terms in that other modern award. However, the FWC must not extend the coverage of those terms to classes of employees that they did not previously cover.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s154/1.content: A modern award must not include terms and conditions of employment (State‑based difference terms)that: General rule—State‑based difference terms must not be included

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s154/1/a.content: are determined by reference to State or Territory boundaries; or

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s154/1/b.content: are expressed to operate in one or more, but not every, State and Territory. When State‑based difference terms may be included

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s154/2.content: However, a modern award may include State‑based difference terms if the terms were included in the award:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s154/2/a.content: in the award modernisation process; or

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s154/2/b.content: in accordance with subsection(3); but only for up to 5 years starting on the day on which the first modern award that included those terms came into operation.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s154/3/a.content: a modern award includes State‑based difference terms as permitted under subsection(2); and

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s154/3/b.content: the FWC is making or varying another modern award so that it (rather than the modern award referred to in paragraph(a)) will cover some or all of the classes of employees who are covered by those terms; the FWC may include those terms in that other modern award. However, the FWC must not extend the coverage of those terms to classes of employees that they did not previously cover.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s155.title: Terms dealing with long service leave
/au-federal/fwa/2009/s155.content:
A modern award must not include terms dealing with long service leave.
CollapseDivision 4A—4 yearly reviews of default fund terms of modern awards
Subdivision A—4 yearly reviews of default fund terms

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156A.title: 4 yearly reviews of default fund terms
/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156A.content:
Timing of 4 yearly reviews
(1)The FWC must conduct a 4 yearly review of default fund terms of modern awards starting as soon as practicable after each 4th anniversary of the commencement of this Part.
Two stages of the 4 yearly reviews
(2)There are 2 stages of the 4 yearly review.
First stage—the Default Superannuation List
(3)In the first stage, the FWC must make the Default Superannuation List for the purposes of the review.
Second stage—reviewing and varying default fund terms
(4)In the second stage, the FWC:
(a)must review the default fund term of each modern award; and
(b)must make a determination varying the term in accordance with section156H; and
(c)if section156J applies—must make a determination varying the term in accordance with that section.
The Schedule of Approved Employer MySuper Products
(5)In the 4 yearly review, the FWC must also make the Schedule of Approved Employer MySuper Products.
Subdivision B—The first stage of the 4 yearly review

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156A/1.content: The FWC must conduct a 4 yearly review of default fund terms of modern awards starting as soon as practicable after each 4th anniversary of the commencement of this Part. Timing of 4 yearly reviews Two stages of the 4 yearly reviews

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156A/2.content: There are 2 stages of the 4 yearly review. First stage—the Default Superannuation List

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156A/3.content: In the first stage, the FWC must make the Default Superannuation List for the purposes of the review. Second stage—reviewing and varying default fund terms

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156A/4.content: In the second stage, the FWC:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156A/4/a.content: must review the default fund term of each modern award; and

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156A/4/b.content: must make a determination varying the term in accordance with section156H; and

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156A/4/c.content: if section156J applies—must make a determination varying the term in accordance with that section. The Schedule of Approved Employer MySuper Products

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156A/5.content: In the 4 yearly review, the FWC must also make the Schedule of Approved Employer MySuper Products. Subdivision B—The first stage of the 4 yearly review

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156B.title: Making the Default Superannuation List
/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156B.content:
(1)In the 4 yearly review, the FWC must make and publish theDefault Superannuation List.
(2)The Default Superannuation List must specify each standard MySuper product that the FWC has determined under section156E is to be included on the list.
(3)The Default Superannuation List must not specify any other product.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156B/1.content: In the 4 yearly review, the FWC must make and publish theDefault Superannuation List.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156B/2.content: The Default Superannuation List must specify each standard MySuper product that the FWC has determined under section156E is to be included on the list.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156B/3.content: The Default Superannuation List must not specify any other product.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156C.title: Applications to list a standard MySuper product
/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156C.content:
(1)Before making the Default Superannuation List, the FWC must publish a notice that invites superannuation funds that offer a standard MySuper product to apply to the FWC to have the product included on the list.
(2)The notice must specify the period in which an application may be made.
(3)After the notice is published, a superannuation fund that offers a standard MySuper product may make a written application to have the product included on the list.
(4)The application must:
(a)be made in the period specified in the notice; and
(b)be accompanied by any fees that are prescribed by the regulations; and
(c)provide information relating to the first stage criteria.
(5)The FWC must publish any application made under subsection(3).
(6)However, if an application includes information that is claimed by the superannuation fund to be confidential or commercially sensitive, and the FWC is satisfied that the information is confidential or commercially sensitive:
(a)the FWC may decide not to publish the information; and
(b)if it does so, it must instead publish a summary of the information which contains sufficient detail to allow a reasonable understanding of the substance of the information (without disclosing anything that is confidential or commercially sensitive).
(7)A reference in this Act (other than in this section) in relation to an application made under subsection(3) includes a reference to a summary referred to in paragraph(6)(b).

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156C/1.content: Before making the Default Superannuation List, the FWC must publish a notice that invites superannuation funds that offer a standard MySuper product to apply to the FWC to have the product included on the list.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156C/2.content: The notice must specify the period in which an application may be made.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156C/3.content: After the notice is published, a superannuation fund that offers a standard MySuper product may make a written application to have the product included on the list.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156C/4/a.content: be made in the period specified in the notice; and

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156C/4/b.content: be accompanied by any fees that are prescribed by the regulations; and

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156C/4/c.content: provide information relating to the first stage criteria.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156C/5.content: The FWC must publish any application made under subsection(3).

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156C/6.content: However, if an application includes information that is claimed by the superannuation fund to be confidential or commercially sensitive, and the FWC is satisfied that the information is confidential or commercially sensitive:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156C/6/a.content: the FWC may decide not to publish the information; and

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156C/6/b.content: if it does so, it must instead publish a summary of the information which contains sufficient detail to allow a reasonable understanding of the substance of the information (without disclosing anything that is confidential or commercially sensitive).

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156C/7.content: A reference in this Act (other than in this section) in relation to an application made under subsection(3) includes a reference to a summary referred to in paragraph(6)(b).

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156D.title: Submissions on applications to list a standard MySuper product
/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156D.content:
(1)The FWC must ensure that all persons and bodies have a reasonable opportunity to make written submissions to the FWC in relation to an application made under subsection156C(3).
(2)If:
(a)a person or body makes a written submission in relation to an application made under subsection156C(3); and
(b)the person or body has an interest in relation to:
(i)the superannuation fund that made the application; or
(ii)if the person or body refers to another superannuation fund in the submission—that superannuation fund;
then the person or body must disclose that interest in the submission.
(3)The FWC must publish any submission that is made.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156D/1.content: The FWC must ensure that all persons and bodies have a reasonable opportunity to make written submissions to the FWC in relation to an application made under subsection156C(3).

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156D/2/a.content: a person or body makes a written submission in relation to an application made under subsection156C(3); and

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156D/2/b.content: the person or body has an interest in relation to:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156D/2/i.content: the superannuation fund that made the application; or

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156D/2/ii.content: if the person or body refers to another superannuation fund in the submission—that superannuation fund; then the person or body must disclose that interest in the submission.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156D/3.content: The FWC must publish any submission that is made.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156E.title: Determining applications to list a standard MySuper product
/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156E.content:
(1)If an application is made under subsection156C(3) to have a standard MySuper product included on the Default Superannuation List, the FWC must make a determination about whether to include the product on the list.
(2)The FWC must not determine that the product is to be included on the list unless, taking into account:
(a)the information provided in the application; and
(b)the first stage criteria; and
(c)any submissions that were made in relation to the application;
the FWC is satisfied that including the product on the list would be in the best interests of default fund employees to whom modern awards apply or a particular class of those employees.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156E/1.content: If an application is made under subsection156C(3) to have a standard MySuper product included on the Default Superannuation List, the FWC must make a determination about whether to include the product on the list.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156E/2.content: The FWC must not determine that the product is to be included on the list unless, taking into account:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156E/2/a.content: the information provided in the application; and

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156E/2/c.content: any submissions that were made in relation to the application; the FWC is satisfied that including the product on the list would be in the best interests of default fund employees to whom modern awards apply or a particular class of those employees.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156F.title: First stage criteria

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156F/a.content: the appropriateness of the MySuper product’s long term investment return target and risk profile; Thefirst stage criteriaare as follows:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156F/b.content: the superannuation fund’s expected ability to deliver on the MySuper product’s long term investment return target, given its risk profile;

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156F/c.content: the appropriateness of the fees and costs associated with the MySuper product, given:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156F/i.content: any other matters the FWC considers relevant. Subdivision C—Second stage of the 4 yearly review

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156F/ii.content: the quality and timeliness of services provided;

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156F/d.content: the net returns on contributions invested in the MySuper product;

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156F/e.content: whether the superannuation fund’s governance practices are consistent with meeting the best interests of members of the fund, including whether there are mechanisms in place to deal with conflict of interest;

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156F/f.content: the appropriateness of any insurance offered in relation to the MySuper product;

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156F/g.content: the quality of advice given to a member of the superannuation fund relating to the member’s existing interest in the fund and products offered by the fund;

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156F/h.content: the administrative efficiency of the superannuation fund;

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156G.title: Review of the default fund term of modern awards
/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156G.content:
(1)As soon as practicable after the Default Superannuation List is made, the FWC must review the default fund term of each modern award.
(2)The FWC must ensure that the following persons have a reasonable opportunity to make written submissions (including submissions requesting that a particular superannuation fund be specified in the term in relation to a standard MySuper product) to the FWC in relation to the default fund term of the award:
(a)an employee and employer that are covered by the modern award;
(b)an organisation that is entitled to represent the industrial interests of one or more employees or employers that are covered by the award;
(c)if the award includes an outworker term—an organisation that is entitled to represent the industrial interests of one or more outworkers to whom the outworker term relates.
(3)If:
(a)a person or body (whether or not a person referred to in subsection(2)) makes a written submission in relation to the default fund term of a modern award; and
(b)the person or body refers to a particular superannuation fund in the submission; and
(c)the person or body has an interest in relation to that superannuation fund;
then the person or body must disclose that interest in the submission.
(4)The FWC must publish any submission that is made.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156G/1.content: As soon as practicable after the Default Superannuation List is made, the FWC must review the default fund term of each modern award.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156G/2.content: The FWC must ensure that the following persons have a reasonable opportunity to make written submissions (including submissions requesting that a particular superannuation fund be specified in the term in relation to a standard MySuper product) to the FWC in relation to the default fund term of the award:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156G/2/a.content: an employee and employer that are covered by the modern award;

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156G/2/b.content: an organisation that is entitled to represent the industrial interests of one or more employees or employers that are covered by the award;

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156G/2/c.content: if the award includes an outworker term—an organisation that is entitled to represent the industrial interests of one or more outworkers to whom the outworker term relates.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156G/3/a.content: a person or body (whether or not a person referred to in subsection(2)) makes a written submission in relation to the default fund term of a modern award; and

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156G/3/b.content: the person or body refers to a particular superannuation fund in the submission; and

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156G/3/c.content: the person or body has an interest in relation to that superannuation fund; then the person or body must disclose that interest in the submission.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156G/4.content: The FWC must publish any submission that is made.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156H.title: Default fund term must specify certain superannuation funds
/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156H.content:
(1)After reviewing the default fund term of a modern award, the FWC must make a determination varying the term:
(a)to remove every superannuation fund that is specified in the term; and
(b)to specify at least 2, but no more than 15, superannuation funds in relation to standard MySuper products that satisfy the second stage test.
(2)A standard MySuper product satisfies thesecond stage testif:
(a)it is on the Default Superannuation List; and
(b)the FWC is satisfied that specifying a superannuation fund in relation to the product in the default fund term of the modern award would be in the best interests of the default fund employees to whom the modern award applies, taking into account:
(i)any submissions that were made in relation to the default fund term of the award; and
(ii)any other matter the FWC considers relevant.
(3)The default fund term may specify more than 15 superannuation funds in relation to standard MySuper products that satisfy the second stage test if, taking into account the range of occupations of employees covered by the modern award, the FWC is satisfied it is warranted.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156H/1.content: After reviewing the default fund term of a modern award, the FWC must make a determination varying the term:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156H/1/a.content: to remove every superannuation fund that is specified in the term; and

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156H/1/b.content: to specify at least 2, but no more than 15, superannuation funds in relation to standard MySuper products that satisfy the second stage test.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156H/2.content: A standard MySuper product satisfies thesecond stage testif:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156H/2/a.content: it is on the Default Superannuation List; and

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156H/2/b.content: the FWC is satisfied that specifying a superannuation fund in relation to the product in the default fund term of the modern award would be in the best interests of the default fund employees to whom the modern award applies, taking into account:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156H/2/i.content: any submissions that were made in relation to the default fund term of the award; and

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156H/2/ii.content: any other matter the FWC considers relevant.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156H/3.content: The default fund term may specify more than 15 superannuation funds in relation to standard MySuper products that satisfy the second stage test if, taking into account the range of occupations of employees covered by the modern award, the FWC is satisfied it is warranted.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156J.title: Variation to comply with section149D
/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156J.content: If, at the time of the 4 yearly review, the default fund term of a modern award does not comply with section149D, the FWC must make a determination varying the term so that it does.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156K.title: Transitional authorisation for certain superannuation funds
/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156K.content:
(1)The FWC may make a transitional authorisation in relation to a superannuation fund (other than a superannuation fund referred to in subsection149D(1), (1A), (2), (3) or (4)) if, at the time of the 4 yearly review, the FWC is satisfied that it is appropriate to make the authorisation.
(2)The transitional authorisation comes into operation on the day it is made and ceases to be in operation on the day specified in the authorisation.
Subdivision D—The Schedule of Approved Employer MySuper Products

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156K/1.content: The FWC may make a transitional authorisation in relation to a superannuation fund (other than a superannuation fund referred to in subsection149D(1), (1A), (2), (3) or (4)) if, at the time of the 4 yearly review, the FWC is satisfied that it is appropriate to make the authorisation.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156K/2.content: The transitional authorisation comes into operation on the day it is made and ceases to be in operation on the day specified in the authorisation. Subdivision D—The Schedule of Approved Employer MySuper Products

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156L.title: The Schedule of Approved Employer MySuper Products
/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156L.content:
(1)In the 4 yearly review, the FWC must:
(a)make and publish theSchedule of Approved Employer MySuper Products; and
(b)revoke any previous Schedule of Approved Employer MySuper Products.
(2)When the schedule is made, it must specify any employer MySuper product that the FWC has determined under section156P is to be included on the schedule.
(3)After the schedule is made, it must be amended to specify any employer MySuper product that the FWC has determined under section156P is to be included on the schedule.
(4)If the schedule is amended as referred to in subsection(3), the FWC must publish the schedule as amended.
(5)The schedule must not specify any other product.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156L/1.content: In the 4 yearly review, the FWC must:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156L/1/a.content: make and publish theSchedule of Approved Employer MySuper Products; and

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156L/1/b.content: revoke any previous Schedule of Approved Employer MySuper Products.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156L/2.content: When the schedule is made, it must specify any employer MySuper product that the FWC has determined under section156P is to be included on the schedule.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156L/3.content: After the schedule is made, it must be amended to specify any employer MySuper product that the FWC has determined under section156P is to be included on the schedule.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156L/4.content: If the schedule is amended as referred to in subsection(3), the FWC must publish the schedule as amended.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156L/5.content: The schedule must not specify any other product.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156M.title: FWC to invite applications to include employer MySuper products on schedule
/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156M.content:
(1)Before making the schedule, the FWC must publish a notice that invites:
(a)superannuation funds that offer an employer MySuper product; and
(b)employers to which an employer MySuper product relates;
to apply to the FWC to have the product included on the schedule.
(2)The notice must specify the period in which an application may be made.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156M/1.content: Before making the schedule, the FWC must publish a notice that invites:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156M/1/a.content: superannuation funds that offer an employer MySuper product; and

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156M/1/b.content: employers to which an employer MySuper product relates; to apply to the FWC to have the product included on the schedule.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156M/2.content: The notice must specify the period in which an application may be made.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156N.title: Making applications to include employer MySuper products on schedule
/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156N.content:
(1)The following may apply to the FWC to have an employer MySuper product included on the schedule:
(a)a superannuation fund that offers the product;
(b)an employer to which the product relates.
(2)The application must be made:
(a)in the period (thestandard application period) specified in the notice under section156M; or
(b)in the period (theinterim application period) that:
(i)starts immediately after the schedule is made under paragraph156L(1)(a); and
(ii)ends immediately before the next 4th anniversary of the commencement of this Part.
(3)The application must also:
(a)be accompanied by any fees that are prescribed by the regulations; and
(b)provide information relating to the first stage criteria.
(4)The FWC must publish any application made under subsection(1).
(5)However, if an application includes information that is claimed by the applicant to be confidential or commercially sensitive, and the FWC is satisfied that the information is confidential or commercially sensitive:
(a)the FWC may decide not to publish the information; and
(b)if it does so, it must instead publish a summary of the information which contains sufficient detail to allow a reasonable understanding of the substance of the information (without disclosing anything that is confidential or commercially sensitive).
(6)A reference in this Act (other than in this section) in relation to an application made under subsection(1) includes a reference to a summary referred to in paragraph(5)(b).
(7)Only one application in relation to an employer MySuper product may be made under subsection(1) in the period that:
(a)starts at the start of the standard application period; and
(b)ends at the end of the interim application period.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156N/1.content: The following may apply to the FWC to have an employer MySuper product included on the schedule:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156N/1/a.content: a superannuation fund that offers the product;

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156N/1/b.content: an employer to which the product relates.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156N/2/a.content: in the period (thestandard application period) specified in the notice under section156M; or

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156N/2/b.content: in the period (theinterim application period) that:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156N/2/i.content: starts immediately after the schedule is made under paragraph156L(1)(a); and

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156N/2/ii.content: ends immediately before the next 4th anniversary of the commencement of this Part.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156N/3/a.content: be accompanied by any fees that are prescribed by the regulations; and

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156N/3/b.content: provide information relating to the first stage criteria.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156N/4.content: The FWC must publish any application made under subsection(1).

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156N/5.content: However, if an application includes information that is claimed by the applicant to be confidential or commercially sensitive, and the FWC is satisfied that the information is confidential or commercially sensitive:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156N/5/a.content: the FWC may decide not to publish the information; and

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156N/5/b.content: if it does so, it must instead publish a summary of the information which contains sufficient detail to allow a reasonable understanding of the substance of the information (without disclosing anything that is confidential or commercially sensitive).

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156N/6.content: A reference in this Act (other than in this section) in relation to an application made under subsection(1) includes a reference to a summary referred to in paragraph(5)(b).

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156N/7.content: Only one application in relation to an employer MySuper product may be made under subsection(1) in the period that:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156N/7/a.content: starts at the start of the standard application period; and

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156N/7/b.content: ends at the end of the interim application period.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156P.title: FWC to determine applications
/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156P.content:
(1)If an application is made under subsection156N(1) to have an employer MySuper product included on the schedule, the FWC must make a determination about whether to include the product on the schedule.
(2)The FWC must not determine that the product is to be included on the schedule unless the product satisfies the first stage test and the second stage test.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156P/1.content: If an application is made under subsection156N(1) to have an employer MySuper product included on the schedule, the FWC must make a determination about whether to include the product on the schedule.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156P/2.content: The FWC must not determine that the product is to be included on the schedule unless the product satisfies the first stage test and the second stage test.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156Q.title: The first stage test
/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156Q.content:
An employer MySuper product satisfies thefirst stage testif the FWC is satisfied that including the product on the Schedule of Approved Employer MySuper Products would be in the best interests of default fund employees, or a particular class of those employees, taking into account:
(a)the information provided in the application; and
(b)the first stage criteria; and
(c)any submissions that were made in relation to whether the product satisfies the first stage test.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156Q/a.content: the information provided in the application; and An employer MySuper product satisfies thefirst stage testif the FWC is satisfied that including the product on the Schedule of Approved Employer MySuper Products would be in the best interests of default fund employees, or a particular class of those employees, taking into account:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156Q/c.content: any submissions that were made in relation to whether the product satisfies the first stage test.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156R.title: Submissions about the first stage test
/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156R.content:
(1)The FWC must ensure that all persons and bodies have a reasonable opportunity to make written submissions to the FWC about whether an employer MySuper product satisfies the first stage test.
(2)If:
(a)a person or body makes a written submission in relation to whether an employer MySuper product satisfies the first stage test; and
(b)the person or body has an interest in relation to:
(i)the superannuation fund that offers the product; or
(ii)if the person or body refers to another superannuation fund in the submission—that superannuation fund;
then the person or body must disclose that interest in the submission.
(3)The FWC must publish any submission that is made.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156R/1.content: The FWC must ensure that all persons and bodies have a reasonable opportunity to make written submissions to the FWC about whether an employer MySuper product satisfies the first stage test.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156R/2/a.content: a person or body makes a written submission in relation to whether an employer MySuper product satisfies the first stage test; and

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156R/2/b.content: the person or body has an interest in relation to:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156R/2/i.content: the superannuation fund that offers the product; or

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156R/2/ii.content: if the person or body refers to another superannuation fund in the submission—that superannuation fund; then the person or body must disclose that interest in the submission.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156R/3.content: The FWC must publish any submission that is made.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156S.title: The second stage test
/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156S.content:
An employer MySuper product satisfies thesecond stage testif the FWC is satisfied that including the product on the Schedule of Approved Employer MySuper Products would be in the best interests of default fund employees of an employer to which the product relates, or a particular class of those employees, taking into account:
(a)any submissions that were made in relation to whether the product satisfies the second stage test; and
(b)any other matter the FWC considers relevant.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156S/a.content: any submissions that were made in relation to whether the product satisfies the second stage test; and An employer MySuper product satisfies thesecond stage testif the FWC is satisfied that including the product on the Schedule of Approved Employer MySuper Products would be in the best interests of default fund employees of an employer to which the product relates, or a particular class of those employees, taking into account:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156S/b.content: any other matter the FWC considers relevant.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156T.title: Submissions about the second stage test
/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156T.content:
(1)The FWC must ensure that the following persons have a reasonable opportunity to make written submissions to the FWC about whether an employer MySuper product satisfies the second stage test:
(a)an employee of an employer to which the product relates;
(b)an employer to which the product relates;
(c)an organisation that is entitled to represent the industrial interests of a person referred to in paragraph(a) or (b).
(2)If:
(a)a person or body (whether or not a person referred to in subsection(1)) makes a written submission in relation to whether an employer MySuper product satisfies the second stage test; and
(b)the person or body has an interest in relation to:
(i)the superannuation fund that offers the product; or
(ii)if the person or body refers to another superannuation fund in the submission—that superannuation fund;
then the person or body must disclose that interest in the submission.
(3)The FWC must publish any submission that is made.
Subdivision E—Publishing documents under this Division

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156T/1.content: The FWC must ensure that the following persons have a reasonable opportunity to make written submissions to the FWC about whether an employer MySuper product satisfies the second stage test:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156T/1/a.content: an employee of an employer to which the product relates;

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156T/1/b.content: an employer to which the product relates;

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156T/1/c.content: an organisation that is entitled to represent the industrial interests of a person referred to in paragraph(a) or (b).

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156T/2/a.content: a person or body (whether or not a person referred to in subsection(1)) makes a written submission in relation to whether an employer MySuper product satisfies the second stage test; and

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156T/2/b.content: the person or body has an interest in relation to:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156T/2/i.content: the superannuation fund that offers the product; or

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156T/2/ii.content: if the person or body refers to another superannuation fund in the submission—that superannuation fund; then the person or body must disclose that interest in the submission.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156T/3.content: The FWC must publish any submission that is made. Subdivision E—Publishing documents under this Division

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156U.title: Publishing documents under this Division
/au-federal/fwa/2009/s156U.content: Subdivision A—Exercise of powers if necessary to achieve modern awards objective

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s157.title: FWC may vary etc. modern awards if necessary to achieve modern awards objective
/au-federal/fwa/2009/s157.content:
(1)The FWC may:
(a)make a determination varying a modern award, otherwise than to vary modern award minimum wages or to vary a default fund term of the award; or
(b)make a modern award; or
(c)make a determination revoking a modern award;
if the FWC is satisfied that making the determination or modern award is necessary to achieve the modern awards objective.
(2)The FWC may make a determination varying modern award minimum wages if the FWC is satisfied that:
(a)the variation of modern award minimum wages is justified by work value reasons; and
(b)making the determination outside the system of annual wage reviews is necessary to achieve the modern awards objective.
(2A)Work value reasonsare reasons justifying the amount that employees should be paid for doing a particular kind of work, being reasons related to any of the following:
(a)the nature of the work;
(b)the level of skill or responsibility involved in doing the work;
(c)the conditions under which the work is done.
(2B)The FWC’s consideration of work value reasons must:
(a)be free of assumptions based on gender; and
(b)include consideration of whether historically the work has been undervalued because of assumptions based on gender.
(3)The FWC may make a determination or modern award under this section:
(a)on its own initiative; or
(b)on application under section158.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s157/1/a.content: make a determination varying a modern award, otherwise than to vary modern award minimum wages or to vary a default fund term of the award; or

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s157/1/c.content: make a determination revoking a modern award; if the FWC is satisfied that making the determination or modern award is necessary to achieve the modern awards objective.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s157/2.content: The FWC may make a determination varying modern award minimum wages if the FWC is satisfied that:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s157/2/a.content: be free of assumptions based on gender; and

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s157/2/b.content: include consideration of whether historically the work has been undervalued because of assumptions based on gender.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s157/2/c.content: the conditions under which the work is done. (2B)The FWC’s consideration of work value reasons must:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s157/3.content: The FWC may make a determination or modern award under this section:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s158.title: Applications to vary, revoke or make modern award
/au-federal/fwa/2009/s158.content:
(1)The following table sets out who may apply for the making of a determination varying or revoking a modern award, or for the making of a modern award, under section157:
Who may make an application?
This kind of application …
may be made by …
an application to vary, omit or include terms (other than outworker terms or coverage terms) in a modern award
(a) an employer, employee or organisation that is covered by the modern award; or
(b) an organisation that is entitled to represent the industrial interests of one or more employers or employees that are covered by the modern award.
an application to vary, omit or include outworker terms in a modern award
(a) an employer, employee or outworker entity that is or would be covered by the outworker terms; or
(b) an organisation that is entitled to represent the industrial interests of one or more outworkers to whom the outworker terms relate or would relate.
an application to vary or include coverage terms in a modern award to increase the range of employers, employees or organisations that are covered by the award
(a) an employer, employee or organisation that would become covered by the modern award; or
(b) an organisationthat is entitled to represent the industrial interests of one or more employers or employees that would become covered by the modern award.
an application to vary or include coverage terms in a modern award to increase the range of outworker entities that are covered by outworker terms
(a) an outworker entity that would become covered by the outworker terms; or
(b) an organisation that is entitled to represent the industrial interests of one or more outworkers who would become outworkers to whom the outworker terms relate.
an application to vary or omit coverage terms in a modern award to reduce the range of employers, employees or organisations that are covered by the award
(a) an employer, employee or organisation that would stop being covered by the modern award; or
(b) an organisation that is entitled to represent the industrial interests of one or more employers or employees that would stop being covered by the modern award.
an application to vary or omit coverage terms in a modern award to reduce the range of outworker entities that are covered by outworker terms
(a) an outworker entity that would stop being covered by the outworker terms; or
(b) an organisation that is entitled to represent the industrial interests of one or more outworkers who would stop being outworkers to whom the outworker terms relate.
an application for the making of a modern award
(a) an employee or employer that would be covered by the modern award; or
(b) an organisation that is entitled to represent the industrial interests of one or more employers or employees that would be covered by the modern award.
an application to revoke a modern award
(a) an employer, employee or organisation that is covered by the modern award; or
(b) an organisation that is entitled to represent the industrial interests of one or more employers or employees that are covered by the modern award.
(2)Subject to the requirements of the table about who can make what kind of application, an applicant may make applications for 2 or more related things at the same time.
Subdivision B—Other situations

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s158/1.content: The following table sets out who may apply for the making of a determination varying or revoking a modern award, or for the making of a modern award, under section157: Who may make an application? This kind of application … may be made by … an application to vary, omit or include terms (other than outworker terms or coverage terms) in a modern award

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s158/1/a.content: an employer, employee or organisation that is covered by the modern award; or

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s158/1/b.content: an organisation that is entitled to represent the industrial interests of one or more employers or employees that are covered by the modern award.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s158/2.content: Subject to the requirements of the table about who can make what kind of application, an applicant may make applications for 2 or more related things at the same time. Subdivision B—Other situations

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s159.title: Variation of modern award to update or omit name of employer, organisation or outworker entity
/au-federal/fwa/2009/s159.content:
(1)The FWC may make a determination varying a modern award:
(a)to reflect a change in the name of an employer, organisation or outworker entity; or
(b)to omit the name of an organisation, employer or outworker entity from the modern award, if:
(i)the registration of the organisation has been cancelled under theWorkplace Relations Act 1996; or
(ii)the employer, organisation or outworker entity has ceased to exist; or
(c)if the modern award is a named employer award and the named employer is the old employer in a transfer of business—to reflect the transfer of business to the new employer.
(2)The FWC may make a determination under this section:
(a)in any case—on its own initiative; or
(b)if paragraph(1)(a) or (b) applies—on application by the employer, organisation or outworker entity referred to in that paragraph; or
(c)if paragraph(1)(c) applies—on application by:
(i)the old employer or the new employer; or
(ii)a transferring employee who was covered by the modern award as an employee of the old employer; or
(iii)an organisation that is entitled to represent the industrial interests of the old employer, the new employer, or one or more employees referred to in subparagraph(ii).

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s159/1.content: The FWC may make a determination varying a modern award:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s159/1/a.content: to reflect a change in the name of an employer, organisation or outworker entity; or

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s159/1/b.content: to omit the name of an organisation, employer or outworker entity from the modern award, if:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s159/1/i.content: the registration of the organisation has been cancelled under theWorkplace Relations Act 1996; or

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s159/1/ii.content: the employer, organisation or outworker entity has ceased to exist; or

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s159/1/c.content: if the modern award is a named employer award and the named employer is the old employer in a transfer of business—to reflect the transfer of business to the new employer.

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s159/2.content: The FWC may make a determination under this section:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s159/2/a.content: in any case—on its own initiative; or

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s159/2/b.content: if paragraph(1)(a) or (b) applies—on application by the employer, organisation or outworker entity referred to in that paragraph; or

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s159/2/i.content: the old employer or the new employer; or

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s159/2/ii.content: a transferring employee who was covered by the modern award as an employee of the old employer; or

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s159/2/iii.content: an organisation that is entitled to represent the industrial interests of the old employer, the new employer, or one or more employees referred to in subparagraph(ii).

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s159A.title: Variation of default fund term of modern award

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s159A/1.content: The FWC may make a determination varying the default fund term of a modern award in relation to a superannuation fund specified in the term in relation to a standard MySuper product (thespecified product) in the following circumstances:

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s159A/1/a.content: to reflect a change in the name of the fund or the specified product;

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s159A/1/b.content: if the fund has ceased to exist—to omit the name of the fund and the specified product;

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s159A/1/c.content: if the specified product has ceased to exist and no other MySuper product is specified in relation to the fund—to omit the name of the fund and the specified product;

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s159A/1/d.content: if the specified product has ceased to exist and another MySuper product is specified in relation to the fund—to omit the name of the specified product;

/au-federal/fwa/2009/s159A/1/e.content: if the Australian Prudential Regulation Authority gives the FWC notice under subsection29U(4) of theSuperannuation Industry (Supervision) Act 1993that the fund no longer offers the specified product and no other MySuper product is specified in relation to the fund—to omit the name of the fund and the specified product;
